Ottawa, September 7, 1937.

Memorandum

Deputy Minister

With reference to Mr. Jackson's memorandum of the 31st ultimo regarding coal and wood for the Brandon Indian Residential School, I would point out that all fuel at residential schools is purchased by the school authorities and paid for by them.

There is no information on file indicating from whom the principal of the Brandon Residential School purchased coal and wood.

Director.

Sep 7'37
Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Oct. 5, 1937.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

I beg to make requisition for lumber:

The flooring of the stalls in the Horse Stable is entirely worn through and must be replaced. It will require 800 lumber ft. for this purpose. The best price we can get for the lumber suitable for this purpose is at $48.00 per M, which amounts to $38.40.

Hockey is our main winter recreation. Our boys are becoming quite proficient and frequently play with other teams in this vicinity. We need lumber for a 2 foot fence around the skating rink. In looking into the matter we find a 12-inch board, undressed, which is a full inch in width, to be the most serviceable material we can secure. It requires 1,000 ft. to make this necessary fence 2 feet high around the rink. The stakes can be cut in the bush and drive them in the ground for our uprights to which we nail the boards. The cost of this lumber is $45.00 per M.

This makes a total bill of $83.40.

We will appreciate it very much if these two items of lumber can be supplied to us by the Department.

I am, Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle
Principal.
Ottawa,
October 12, 1937.

Reverend Sir:

EX'D.

With reference to your letter of October 5th, you may incur an expenditure of $3.40 for the purchase of lumber to replace the flooring of the stalls in the horse stable and also to erect a fence around the skating rink.

Yours truly,

R.A. Boey,
Supt. of Welfare & Education.

Dr. J.A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.
Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Oct. 8, 1937

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to our letter of October 4th, making request for lumber, for stall floors in the horse barn and for two foot wall around our skating rink, I have just learned that the A. R. McIarmid Company, from whom we have been purchasing these supplies has ceased handling lumber. The only other firm in this city, from whom we can purchase, is that of Messrs. Wade & Sons.

Awaiting your instruction in this connection,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal.

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Minister

At the present time, the Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School, Brandon, Manitoba, (Electoral District of Brandon) wishes to purchase a small quantity of lumber for floors in the horse barn.

He advises that in the past he has been purchasing lumber from the A.R. McDiarmid Company, Brandon, but this firm has ceased handling lumber.

The Principal further states that the only other firm in Brandon from whom lumber can be obtained is Messrs. Wade & Sons. I would appreciate your advising if it is in order to purchase from this firm.

Dear Sir,

I have received a letter from the Rev. J. A. Doyle, Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School, in which he points out that the windows of the school do not fit and make it almost impossible to heat the building. He states that some of the windows have almost \(\frac{7}{16}\) inch play when moved from side to side. He recommends that the bronze weather stripping, which is nailed on the window frame and presses against the sash, be purchased and points out that it will require 500 ft., at an approximate cost of $16.00 F.O.B. Winnipeg.

Dr. Doyle points out that if the Department will supply the material, he will arrange to have it put on. If funds are available, I would recommend that this request be granted.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.
Ottawa, December 24, 1937.

Yours truly,

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

I quote from a letter just received from Dr. Doyle, Indian Residential School, Brandon, which refers to the need for new dining room tables -

"These tables were made of light and unsuitable material, had no braces whatever, and they were not in use many months until they began to need repairs. Most of them have now reached that condition that they are beyond further repair. Some of them will have to be replaced at once, and the rest in the very near future. I saw a table some weeks ago at one of the other schools which seemed very suitable and has stood up well, and got a quotation from Messrs Wade & Son for a table 2'6" x 8', with cross bars between the legs at the ends, and a brace from these to a cross support in the centre of the table, with battleship linoleum covering, and angle iron in place of a molding around the outside of the table. The price they quote is $22.00 for a single table, or a job rate for the sixteen tables of $20.00 each."

I know the tables are in bad condition and at least a number should be renewed at once. I would be pleased to receive the Department's instructions concerning this matter.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
M. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, Ontario,
July 15, 1938.

Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 11th instant with reference to tables that the principal of the Brandon Residential School requests we supply.

For your information, I may say that in the current year's appropriation, we included an amount of $500 for repairs, improvements, and new equipment at the Brandon Indian Residential School. We have already expended an amount of $33.45 for repairs to the flush tanks, which leaves a balance available of $466.55. If we purchase 16 of the tables recommended by the principal it would involve an expenditure of $320.00.

Before requesting our purchasing agent to do so, I thought it advisable to write you in order that you might again consult the principal and advise him of the amount available, as if the tables are purchased it would only leave a sum of approximately $145 for further repairs and improvements.

As soon as you have the opportunity of discussing the matter with Dr. Doyle, you should let me know how many tables he wishes us to secure, and at the same time you should state the address of Messrs. Wade and Son from whom you recommend the tables be purchased.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 133-0-5 dated July 15th, I wish to report that I was at the Brandon School on July 27th. Dr. Doyle was away on holidays. Unfortunately, I was not aware of this when I left Winnipeg.

I had hoped that we might secure a good carpenter and rebuild the tables, but after seeing their condition and the inferior wood of which they had been constructed, this is out of the question. The tables are a disgrace to the institution and new ones should be provided. I might add that the benches being used are very little better than the tables.

I am not sure that the plan of a table designed by Dr. Doyle is the most satisfactory. I would recommend that the Department draw up a blueprint giving specifications and that different firms be asked to tender. In designing the tables a strip should be morticed in both ends of the table top to prevent warping.

Yours very truly,

A.F.C. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Brandon Indian Residential School, Brandon, Manitoba, Electoral District of Brandon.

It is necessary to build new dining room tables and benches for use at the above-mentioned school. I would appreciate if you would let me have the name of a competent carpenter who could be employed to do this work. We would like to have these tables and benches built as soon as possible and we would, therefore, like to know at the earliest possible date the name of the person to be employed.

Acting Director.

Minister's Office

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Re - Brandon Indian Residential School.

Referring to your memorandum of the 15th instant, file 133-0-5, it will be in order for you to engage Mr. J.C. Benson, 3333 MacDonald Avenue, Brandon, to do the work mentioned.

W.J.P. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

Brandon, Man., Aug. 19, 1938.

The Secretary,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

As we require a new herd sire in connection with our Purebred Shorthorn herd, I thought it advisable to go to Ontario to secure one. I made this trip serve as holiday, and was away just one month.

Dear Inspector Hamilton,

As I stated in conversation the other evening, our water supply continues low. The reservoir on the hill has stood all summer about three feet below the top of the tank, which cuts off our supply for the flush box in the bathroom of our residence. We have had to use a pail all summer in this connection. We have been studying ways and means of lessening the consumption and find that children's baths take a great deal of water and frequently run us short on Saturday, and this shortage sometimes extends over Sunday. The bathing is done on Friday and Saturday as a rule. We find that Y.M.C.A.s and similar institutions have replaced the bath tubs with shower baths. We believe that if properly organized and supervised, we could get through our bathing each week with less than half the amount of water we now use. Then, there is no question that the showers are much more sanitary than tubs.

I have taken the matter up with Yates, Neale & Company and had them estimate on taking out the four tubs on the boys side and three on the girls and placing three shower baths on each side. This of course necessitates fixing the floor and the drain so as to properly care for the water that is used. The enclosed letter is their estimate.

I would appreciate very much your good offices in having this work cared for by the Department, if they approve of same.

We have just been checking over the tables and benches with a view of making what temporary repairs are absolutely necessary in order to carry on till new ones can be secured. We will be glad if this can be done soon.

Again thanking you, I am,

Yours sincerely,

J.A. Doyle (signed)

Dear Sir:

The extremely dry fall we have had is telling seriously on our water supply. Previous shortages have occurred during January and February, but for the past three weeks, at intervals, we have been without water during part of the time. We turn off the water at nights, preventing the automatic flush of the toilets, and conserving any waste that might occur on account of leaking taps; and we have been hauling for most of the stock from Lake Percy.

The main spring to the north of the buildings here, which was investigated either two or three years ago, as far as we can see, seems to be flowing as strongly as ever, and it is the opinion of those who know the situation best, that if this supply were tapped, it would give us adequate water for all our purposes.

We are also endeavouring to find a new spring along the bottom of this elevation where the School is situated, hoping to get a supply for the stock without having to haul it the way we are doing at present.

I will keep you informed from time to time in regard to the situation, as to whether it becomes better or worse. I am

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir,

I wish to acknowledge Department letter 133-0-5 dated November 19th and to report that I have discussed with Dr. Doyle, the principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School the question of a new garage.

It is necessary to build a garage large enough to accommodate one car and two trucks. The large truck is approximately 22 feet long from bumper to bumper. Consequently it will be necessary to have a building 24 ft. wide and 28 ft. long. This allows 8 ft. for each of the car and small truck and 12 ft. for the truck. The old garage is constructed of cement and, in my opinion, it is not a safe place to store cars. The location, I think, is the one most suitable. Dear Sir:

The water situation here continues to give us trouble. A week ago today we were without any water from the spring.

Some time ago we deepened the reservoir and extended the intake pipe down about fourteen inches, which now places the pipe which carries the water out of the reservoir about two feet above the bottom of the well. The water therefore has to siphon out while we are using that last two feet in the bottom of the reservoir. We therefore were without water after the supply was exhausted and air got in the pipe, until the water rose in the reservoir considerably over two feet, as air seems to get in the pipes somewhere and prevent the water running through until there was a fairly good head of pressure. We consulted Yates & Neale about having a valve placed at the bottom of the intake pipe that would automatically close before the tank was quite empty, thereby preventing air from getting in. They looked into the matter and suggested supplying us with a valve belonging to a type of force-pump which would cost together with float, over $5000. So we devised a scheme of our own and had them make it for us. It consists of an elbow on the bottom of the perpendicular pipe, a short piece of horizontal pipe, and another elbow facing up; then had a valve made to cover that opening with a fairly long shaft, a float attached to the end of it and so adjusted that when the water was within an inch or two of the opening, the valve would shut and prevent any more water from flowing until a fresh supply accumulated in the reservoir sufficient to lift the valve and let the water through.

I was glad to learn in our conversation yesterday that progress was being made in regard to securing garage accommodation here in the near future, as the situation in regard to the present garage is very much worse. The risk of collapse has become so imminent that we think it unlikely even a car or truck in for overnight. Some parts of the walls are in danger of falling in, the north wall and the north end of the roof have shifted considerably recently and the roof is so badly cracked that when the snow melts or it rains the water comes through freely.

I would like very much if a garage could be built that could be heated, as in the extreme winter weather it is not only very difficult to get cars started but the grease and oil become so hard that it is injurious to the car during the time it is running until these become soft.

I have checked up on the measurements and find that the two garages suggested 26' x 18' x 9' will accommodate our requirements, providing that one of them has a door space full 16' wide.

The tearing down and removal of at least part of the material of the present garage and the levelling up of the debris to make a fit foundation and floor for the new garage or garages will cost approximately $100.00.

I would think it advisable that this part of the work be done as soon as possible as men could be secured more cheaply before the work of spring commences.

We would certainly appreciate getting this accommodation as early as possible as our large stock, especially, will deteriorate considerably if it has to remain out through all kinds of weather.

Yours sincerely,

J. A. Doyle, (signed)

Dear Inspector Hamilton:

Since our conversation and my subsequent letter in regard to garage accommodation, we have had an intense and prolonged cold spell and have had the most trouble with our trucks that we have ever had in my experience here. It has been almost impossible to get the big truck started after a few days standing by the School with the temperature so far below zero as it has been. This condition would not be improved much if it were in a metal garage in similar temperature.

We have been casting about for any possible saving in the erection of a garage which could be heated and I am satisfied we have found a solution. I believe the best possible place for a garage on these premises would be immediately north of the present School building using the north wall of the Assembly Hall for the south wall and gable end of the garage. We could cut at least two feet off the width, making it thirty instead of thirty-two, facing west, and the front in line with the School building and twenty-six feet deep, as suggested in our previous plan. This, as you see, would save material and work for this south wall and gable. A lot of excavating would have to be done, which we would be able to do ourselves when the frost is out, probably immediately after seeding; in all nearly 300 yards of earth would have to be moved to make way for this building, and the suitable drive-way approaching both doors. This would move the earth back and leave the slope in such condition that it would not give trouble in the future in working in against the building. Then we could put a pipe through from the heating plant, installing a couple of radiators, and thereby be able to heat the building in the most economical way. The only addition that would be required would be a door at the east side, so that the wagons bringing vegetables to the root house could be driven through. It would also be a great convenience to drive a car through rather than back out the distance which
Inspector A.G. Hamilton.

would be required on account of the bank.

I have taken the matter up with Mr. Spratling, and he thinks this can be constructed for about $675.00. There would then be the additional expense of wrecking the old garage. We would use some of the material out of this for the foundation and cement floor of the new garage. The above price includes the cement floor, and we would do the necessary hauling of material.

In viewing the matter from every standpoint, and in talking it over with the men of the Staff and others who are familiar with the situation, this seems to me to be the most feasible arrangement we could possibly make, and we will certainly appreciate it very much if this plan can be carried out.

As we are finding now, as also in the past, the intense frost has a tendency to deflate truck tires. Sunday morning we found five tires of the big truck practically flat, with no sign of puncture or leaking valves, and after working all morning to get the tires up and the truck going, it was too late to take our C.G.I.T. girls to a special service at Knox Church, in which they were to take part.

I know you will give this matter sympathetic consideration.

I am

Yours sincerely,

J. A. Doyle

Dear Sir:

The kitchen range, as I have stated in previous correspondence, has been exceedingly unsatisfactory. It is a three-oven range with a large fire pot at the end. We have never found it possible, no matter how hot a fire we had, to heat the third oven. In fact the top of the stove at that end could not be kept warm enough to keep food hot enough to serve if left standing for any length of time. This meant that all the cooking and baking had to be done either in the first or second oven, and these were so different in the amount of heat they carried that many things had to be removed from one oven to the other, and to cook a dinner pots were continually moved up and down the stove. In addition to these difficulties in cooking the top plates on the stove have been warping and grates have been burning out at frequent intervals. The top of the stove covering the first two sections was seriously warped and both large plates so badly cracked that these have had to be replaced.

Dear Sir:

Re: Brandon Indian Residential School, Water Supply.

Further to my report of the 1st instant on the above matter, I may say that I have again visited the school to make a more thorough investigation of the problem and in this connection I have the following to report:

Upon a close inspection of the three concrete chambers referred to in my previous report, I found that conditions were as described, with one exception, the chambers are 6' x 10' x 10' in size, and have a capacity of 11,250 gallons, and not 18,750 as stated previously. As suggested in my previous report the construction of these tanks appears to be contrary to the best methods, and in my opinion the reason for a shortage of water is a result of this type of construction, and I would therefore recommend that the following work be carried out on these chambers, before any major expenditure is considered:

(1) Since the three chambers are entirely open at the bottom, that is they rest on the sandy floor, I would suggest the use sheet pile, with 3" built-up material, the south wall of the chambers. The material used should be 6' in length in order that it may be driven on the inside of each chamber.

(2) In addition to this work I would suggest that a trench be dug from the South East corner and also from the S. West corner of the block of chambers. This trench would be excavated to a depth of 8', which is the depth of the floor, and would be about 40' in length, as indicated on the attached sketch. In this trench sheet piling should be placed, throughout its entire length, and back-filled with clay, not gravelly soil, of which the local soil consists.

(3) To improve the flow to the tanks I would suggest that three lines of weeping tile be placed in the trenches indicated on the plan. I would suggest that these trenches be excavated to a depth of approximately 6', with of course a grade to the collection chambers, and I believe that it would be of considerable advantage if coarse screened gravel were used in the bottom of the trench, to a depth of at least one foot.
I believe that this proposed work, if carried out, will result in an increase of water during the season of the year when shortages usually take place, but I would strongly recommend that every attempt be made to have this work carried out at the earliest possible moment, in order that the effect of the work could be determined, and not confused with the natural seasonal increase which may be expected quite soon.

My estimate of the cost of this work, is as follows:

- Lumber 110' 3" x 6' Approx. 2,000 F.B.M. $80.00
- Labour, 150 hrs. @ .50¢ 75.00
- Cement, 6 sacks @ 1.00 6.00
- Excavation 150 cu. yds. Labour 200 hrs. @ 35¢ 105.00
- 120 lin. feet weeping tile 4" 15.00

Contingencies 20% approx. 56.00

Total $327.00

You will note by the sketch that we show an old trench, and in this connection I may say that an attempt was made some years ago to increase the storage capacity of the chambers by the placing of sheet piling in the approximate location shown. I am advised that this work was of some value, but it appears to me that the piling would be placed to better advantage on the higher ground.

I sincerely hope that this suggested work will be of benefit if carried out, and if it were possible I should be very happy to look after the work for you.

Faithfully yours,

Sgd. J. Atkinson,
Junior Engineer.

Dear Sir:

When visiting a few evenings ago at the Indian industrial school, I was shown around by Dr. Doyle, the principal. Dr. Doyle is an exceptionally able administrator, as well as a successful principal.

Several repairs and changes at the school are practically imperative without delay, in order to avoid greater expenditure later. The order of necessity would stand somewhat as follows:

1. The water problem still remains. The development of a new stream has helped, but it is yet altogether insufficient for the residence. A small pressure tank at a cost of about $100.00 would be sufficient to overcome this difficulty.

2. The garage, a heavy old cement structure, is falling to pieces. One of the staff will not risk his car in it at all. Repairs to this old tumbledown building are out of the question. The erection of a garage to be in readiness for the coming winter cannot be delayed. Dr. Doyle is most anxious that a workshop for the boys be installed over the garage. Heating facilities can be cheaply taken care of from the main building. The whole trend is in favour of manual training, and this cannot be followed without facilities.

3. The school has entered upon honey production with every promise of success, and much to the interest of the scholars. There is a small building, old and unused, which, if moved to another location, would be made at little cost into a desirable bee house.

4. The gym is over a rough workshop used for repairs to farm implements, etc. Entrance at present to the gym is quite unsuitable and dangerous. Outside stairs could be easily erected, and the present difficulty thereby eliminated.
5. In several places, and particularly at the principal's residence, the eaves troughing is completely gone, and the foundations are being impaired.

6. There is a very nice chapel, but the stage curtains are just about a thing of the past, and should be replaced. Only comparatively small curtains are required.

7. A small sleeping balcony on the east end of the main building should be fitted with mosquito screening. For lack of screening, it is almost impossible to use the balcony at night.

8. There is considerable interior painting that should be done at once during the holidays. This has been necessary for some time, and it would be false economy to disregard the need any longer.

All the above are vitally necessary, and delay in the work would, in my judgment, be a mistake. The main building is an excellent one, and in good shape.

Dr. Doyle is doing very fine work in this school. I was much impressed with the happy, animated expression of the boys and girls, as compared with the stolidity which one might expect.

I would suggest that Mr. E. Fulcher, 402 - 22nd Street, Brandon, be asked to give you estimates on building and repairs, and that Crane Bros. and Geo. Hickling be asked for figures on painting.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) J. E. Matthews.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle,

With further reference to the water supply at the Brandon Indian Residential School, enclosed herewith are copies of a report and plan submitted by Mr. Atkinson under date of the 28th ultimo.

Mr. Atkinson discusses the situation under three heads:

(1) Wells - This would be feasible but would require the installation of pumping equipment and a water softener.

(2) Extension of present source of supply - More water could be obtained but there is no guarantee that the supply would be adequate. This proposal is not favoured by the school officials but their opinions should not be the controlling factor in the case.

(3) Development of springs 1,700 feet north of school - The estimated cost of this project, which would provide an adequate supply, is about $3,700.00. It is favoured strongly by the school authorities and Mr. Atkinson is of the opinion that it should be carried out at the earliest possible date.

Referring to project (3), Mr. Gow in a letter dated October 24th, 1934, stated that this spring showed a substantial flow but that it was used by cattle, presented an unsightly looking source of water supply, and was badly contaminated. He estimated that the clearing up of the spring and improving of the water would cost about $1,500.00. The clearing up of the site and its protection from contamination do not appear to be covered in Mr. Atkinson's estimate. Moreover, if construction is undertaken now it will be under winter conditions with higher costs for all items of work.

From Inspector Hamilton's letter of October 3rd last, it might be inferred that the situation was serious, yet Mr. Atkinson's wire of the 6th item stated that he had examined the system and found no shortage. The school may be operating under a handicap and the extension of the water supply system would undoubtedly be advantageous. However, the existing supply has served requirements for some time and the school has been able to function during this period when it has been one of the driest in the history of Brandon. Under the circumstances and in view of existing conditions we do not feel the expenditure for scheme (3) is justified at present. It is recommended that Engineer Atkinson be requested to investigate scheme (2) and furnish an estimate of cost for consideration.

Dear Sir:

Re: Brandon Indian Residential School Water Supply.

In reference to your request for an inspection of the above mentioned water system, I may say that I have visited the school and made a thorough survey of the whole situation, and have the following to report in this connection:

Regarding the work carried out, at my suggestion and under my direction, during the early summer, I may say that at this time there appears to have been no beneficial results whatsoever. This, of course, is difficult to determine, as the season has been one of the driest in the history of Brandon, but in that the system is still short of water, the benefit, if any, was insufficient for the purpose.

Since it is imperative that an adequate water supply be established, I investigated the available sources of supply, which are as follows:

1. Wells.
2. Additional work in the vicinity of the existing tank and springs.
3. Springs to the North of the school, and at a distance of about 1,700 feet.

Regarding a supply from a system of wells, or from a well, this is undoubtedly quite feasible, but any such scheme would necessitate the installation of storage tanks, and would also depend on pumping. In addition, the water is very hard and would necessitate the installation of a softener.

I am quite convinced that more water could be diverted to the existing tanks by the construction of drainage ditches covering a larger area in the immediate vicinity of the existing water system supply tank. However, I would not suggest that this work be undertaken, as I am convinced that only one project will meet with the approval of the local authorities, and that is the project covered in the next paragraph.

The proposal to connect the school system to the springs to the North of the school has been advocated for a long time, and in that there is apparently an adequate supply for all purposes........

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Re - Water supply, Brandon Indian Residential School.

Confirming advice by telephone yesterday, our Engineer states that his proposal to open up new springs in the vicinity of the present intake is not feasible at the present time and that the only satisfactory plan is to install a new line and take water from the upper spring where the flow is excellent. The upper spring is some 1,700 feet north of the school and has an estimated flow of 28,000 gallons per day.

To undertake the installation of the pipe under winter conditions would cost $4,000.00, including material. Our Chief Engineer points out, however, that the installation of the new pipe in the frozen ground, under frost conditions, would have to be very carefully done as, with frost in the pipe, there is a possibility that the water would freeze just as soon as it reached the pipe. Eventually, the ring of ice would practically fill the pipe at various points.

While the installation could be made, it seems advisable that it be deferred until the spring and water hauled to the extent required. It is very likely that the Indian Agent could obtain the loan of a water tank from the City of Brandon for the winter months and obtain water from the most convenient source of supply.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Water Supply,
Brandon Indian Residential School.

In response to the request contained in Mr. Jackson's memorandum of May 23, I am sending forward herewith copy of a report from the Surveys and Engineering Branch and certain correspondence relating to the above noted subject.

The Brandon Residential School is one of a number of schools at which the water supply appears to be wholly inadequate to meet institutional needs. The same condition exists at the Chapleau Residential School, Chapleau, Ont., and at Sandy Bay Residential School, Manitoba. This condition exists despite the fact that we have been spending large sums of money in recent years to provide an adequate supply of water at a number of schools. There is in the estimates of this year an item of $4,000.00 to pay for the system installed at the Shingwauk Residential School, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont. This work was undertaken and completed last year. I regret to state, however, that it was not possible to include in the estimates of this year the amount of money necessary to undertake the installation of water supply systems at Brandon or the other schools. The total amount included in this year's estimates for repairs and general upkeep at the Brandon school is $500.00.

Honourable T. A. Crerar,

Dear Mr. Crerar:

Previous to leaving for Ottawa I looked over some of the Dominion Government property, and more particularly the Indian Residential School. I there interviewed the Principal, Dr. J. A. Doyle, who I may say is in my judgment one of the most efficient administrators of whom I know. There are several matters in connection with the School that require attention, but with the enormous outlays now compulsory it will probably not be possible to take care of all of them.

The matter of water supply, however, is unavoidable and demands immediate attention. As a matter of fact the fire risk has reached an acute stage.

The large reservoir in the bank above the School which at one time afforded an abundance of water and was almost constantly overflowing, is now practically empty. The intake has been lowered and there is a very small trickle of water running down to the low level of the intake, and the large portion of the earth at the bottom of this reservoir is out of the water. A partial supply of water is taken from a well near the School, but in the case of emergency such as fire this would be entirely inadequate. I have no doubt that the Department has on file details concerning the water supply but I would strongly urge that there be no delay in having this matter receive attention.

There are two small matters which should also immediately be attended to; the eave troughing for two of the barns if neglected any longer will cost much more than at present. The estimated cost some time ago was down to $105.00, but to what extent the foundations have been impaired since then I cannot say.

The other matter is a very trivial one. The School has taken up bee-keeping with, I believe, a good
measure of success, and the boys of the School have become greatly interested. It is not only a matter of instruction, but is even already a matter of revenue which will be increased constantly. Before proceeding it is necessary to move an old building and repair it to some extent at a cost of not over $100.00. If this could be done without delay, it would help the School very decidedly in bee-keeping efforts.

I shall be glad to discuss these matters with you briefly at an early opportunity and I will again emphasize their urgency.

Yours faithfully,

J. E. Matthews,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Water Supply,
Brandon Indian Residential School,
Electoral District of Brandon, Manitoba.

In the current year's appropriation an amount of $2,500.00 is provided for the erection of a new day school at Ahousaht, British Columbia. This building was intended to provide educational facilities for the children in that district owing to the destruction by fire of the main part of the Ahousaht Residential School on January 27, 1940. I have been in communication with Indian Commissioner MacKay and also had a recent interview with Reverend George Dorey, D.D., Associate Secretary, Board of Home Missions, United Church of Canada, who has just returned from a visit to British Columbia.

It has been pointed out that the attendance at the Ahousaht Day School will not be large and that there will be available at this point two buildings, formerly used in connection with the Ahousaht Residential School. One of these buildings can be used for a classroom and the other for a teacher's residence. While these two buildings are situated approximately one-half mile from the village of Ahousaht, there appears to be no necessity for incurring expenditure in erecting another building when the two mentioned are available and will meet our requirements.

Under the above circumstances, I recommend that the money provided for the erection of a school at this -
at this point be used for providing a new water supply at the Brandon Indian Residential School. In this connection I would refer you to Mr. Jackson's memorandum of May 28 and Mr. Pratt's memorandum of May 28, with regard to the communications received from Mr. J. E. Matthews, M. P.

In November, 1939, this Branch arranged with the Surveys and Engineering Branch to have one of their engineers proceed to Brandon and investigate the water situation. He has supplied a report indicating that an adequate water supply can be obtained for an amount not exceeding $4,000.00.

With the amount not used at Ahousaht, plus a sum of $500.00 included in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at the Brandon School, we would have sufficient funds to do this work, which is apparently very necessary, as the school cannot operate successfully under the present water conditions.

I would appreciate it if the Minister would grant the necessary approval.

Director.

As requested, I have visited the above mentioned school in connection with the suggested revision of my original estimate of cost of proposed work because of the suggested use of Indian labour and a foreman contractor. Dear Sir:

I was very glad to hear through my friend Mr. J. E. Mathews, M. P. that definite action had been taken in regard to the water situation in connection with this school. I felt however I should let you know that the situation continues to grow much worse. The spring from which we were getting a partial supply for the live stock has dried up entirely. The well that we opened up at the back of the horse barn from which we got a good supply during the winter does not yield enough for more than three or four horses. Dear Sir:

There are three large barns at the Brandon School, in which are housed some splendid stock, and each fall a large quantity of feed.

Two years ago a fire occurred in the horse barn and but for the fact that prompt action was possible and the experimental farm assisted, I fear that a high-priced barn would have been lost. It is thought the fire started from the overheating of new hay and instant combustion took place.

Ottawa, September 5, 1940.

Memorandum:

MR. ROEY:

While on my holidays I had an opportunity, without any expense to the Department, of inspecting the under-mentioned residential schools:

1. Brandon Indian Residential School.

I was at Brandon on August 27 and went over all the buildings with the Principal, Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D. I found everything in good condition and it should not be necessary to expend any large amount on repairs for some time. The Principal was anxious regarding the water situation and I advised him that as far as we were aware the necessary work would be done in the near future.

Dr. Doyle will reach retirement age in 1941 and expects to leave the Indian work at that time. When the present Brandon school was erected in 1929-30, a principal's residence was not provided, due to the fact that it was considered at that time it was unnecessary to replace the principal's residence, which had been in use for some years. At the present time this building is in very bad repair. Apparently, it is gradually sinking and as a result the floors are warped and the plaster is continually falling. There is no basement under this building, although some years ago a small space was dug to provide for a furnace. In the event of a new principal being appointed next year, it is quite likely we will have a request for extensive repairs to the present building or a new building. At that time the whole question should receive very careful consideration. The present building is extremely large, in fact much larger than is required for a principal's residence at a residential school. Instead of expending the large amount that would be necessary to repair the present building, I am inclined to feel that it would be preferable to erect a new principal's residence.

S. V. Young

Dear Mr. Hamilton:

In reference to the repairs about the School here which we looked over at the time Dr. McGill and yourself were here, I beg to submit the following estimates and suggestions. Contractors have been so busy around here with R.A.F. work that it has taken a little time to get information from them.

Re the roof. The firm of McDowell and Doke examined the roof with me and we found that on many parts of the roof the tar and gravel had completely washed away leaving the roofing paper exposed and already showing signs of weathering. This type of roof I understand should be retarred within ten years, but it is now 12 or 13 years since the roofs were put on. I concur in their recommendation that the entire roof should be cleaned of gravel and re-coated with tar and gravel. The flashings around the edges have in many places worked loose and these will need to be reset and rechinked. At one place on the main roof the roofing paper has split from one side of the building to the other along one of the two ridges. The other ridge needs reinforcing before it likewise splits. Around the hopper on the Chapel roof the paper has become damaged. In these two places the building now leaks.

Their estimate for all of the above work is $390.00. If funds are not available this fall to do the entire roof I would suggest that the two places be repaired and recoated at once and the balance of the roof finished in the spring. This immediate repair work would take about $50.00.

Re the barn. The H.D. Spratling Co. looked over the barns with me. He recommended that the rotted portion of the sills and timbers be cut away, a cement wall be built up about two feet on top of the old foundation, the timbers reset in this wall, the side wall be straightened where it had sagged, new floor joists be put in under the driveway and the other lot of joists spliced with new pieces, and the floor renewed when...
rotted through. He estimated the cost of all this would not be more than $175.00.

We examined the shingles and found those on the south side including the extension in very bad condition, beyond repairing. Mr. Spratling thinks that the north side could be repaired to last a few years, but he estimated the shingling would cost about $400.00.

It is imperative that the wall and floor of the barn be done at once, but I would suggest that if the funds are not available this fall the shingling might be left over until next spring.

Re the chimney on the Principal's residence. This of course is imperative and his estimate was $25.00 to rebuild the chimney from the roof up.

Re the pig-pen, Mr. Spratling is working on estimates for two different ways to overcome the difficulty. As soon as I receive them I will forward them to you, and I hope something can be done about it this fall.

There are some other things around the place that I would like to have fixed up next summer. How soon should I have these items and the estimates of their cost in to you?

Yours truly,

(Signed) R. T. Chapin.
Dear Sir:

The enclosed letter has just been received from Rev. R. T. Chapin, Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School, in connection with various repairs required at the school.

I recommend that the roof be repaired at a cost of $60.00, and provision be made for the completion of this work in 1942.

The barn is in poor condition, and unsafe. This is very essential work and I think the figure of $175.00 is reasonable for the repairs required. If this is left much longer, some boy will be hurt or some valuable stock injured. The barn is well worth repairing.

The shingles should be provided for in next year's estimates. A poor roof makes almost a useless barn.

Dear Sir:

In accordance with our previous conversation, we have prepared a sketch and estimate of the work which should be done on the electrical distribution system of your School. We are enclosing herewith, also, a sheet of symbols which should enable you to interpret the sketch.

The work to be done, as we agreed, is listed as follows:

(1) Pole 2 to be removed and replaced by a new 35 ft. pole about 50 ft. north of present location to skirt preposed Girls' Playground.
(2) Same as Item (1)
(3) Guy and anchor removed and attached to opposite side of Pole 4.
(4) Pole 6 moved 10 ft. north, approximately, to straighten line and clear evergreen tree.
(5) Poles 7, 8, and 9 to be replaced by new 30 ft. poles in view of deterioration of present poles.

In addition to above, we have noted one or two other poles to be replaced near the barns; some tree trimming and wire tightening to be done; and a few other improvements to be made. The total cost of all this work is $179.30.

We suggest that you communicate with your department and recommend that this work be done in the interests of safety.

Yours very truly,

MANITOBA POWER COMMISSION

Electrical Engineer

Brandon, Man., June 9, 1942.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing correspondence which I have just received from the Manitoba Power Commission, in reference to our distribution system within the School property.

A short time ago the electrical engineer and head linesman were here because of a blow-out through lightning. They pointed out to me that in one place particularly, the line was in a very dangerous condition, and so we went over the whole distribution system. At one point between poles 1 and 2, wires are so low that you can almost reach them with an unstretched hand. The insulation on the wires is becoming so old and worn that in some places it is breaking away, leaving the wires in a very dangerous position. By putting a higher pole in at number 2, and moving it to a little higher ground to the north, this danger can be eliminated. I asked them of the possibility of running the wires at the edge of the girls' playground, instead of across it, with the pole in the centre of the playground. This they measured out and considered very feasible indeed advisable, replacing pole number 3 with a higher pole to the north. Near pole number 6 a large shade tree on the edge of the lawn is growing into the wires, and to eliminate danger from
the high voltage wires, this would either have to be cut out or pole number 6 moved farther north. They recommended this latter, as it would also straighten the line. Poles 7, 8 and 9 are deteriorating beneath the ground and becoming somewhat shaky. Likewise two poles near the barns need replacing. The good part of pole number 3 could be used for one of these. So a total of six new poles is required. They are making us allowance for the old poles, as the top parts of them could be utilized in some of their other work. As they pointed out, where we have so many children, it is in the interests of safety to keep the line in good condition, and I would recommend that the improvements be carried on, and ask for authority for them to proceed with the work.

Yours very truly,

Brandon, Man.,
October 16, 1942.

Mr. Clarence Jackson,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Langevin Block,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Clarence:

I called over to the Indian School yesterday to see Mr. Chapin, whom I had met for only a minute a year ago. He seems most anxious to give good service along all lines.

I was glad to find that the added water supply is fairly satisfactory. Without that, they could not have carried on.

Discussing the property, there are of course several major improvements necessary, those to the residence, or a new residence, being just about imperative. Mr. Chapin realizes the present war difficulties, and no one could be more willing to co-operate than he. There are, however, some minor repairs which should be made without any delay so as to avoid further depreciation. No doubt the department has a list of those on file. The roof of the school, for instance, can be repaired now for a much smaller outlay than would soon be necessary. It is steadily deteriorating. There are several other minor matters which a capable man should be able to correct within a reasonable time, and undoubtedly the residence calls for attention before winter sets in.

Capable men are difficult to secure here, at present, but I imagine if you were to take the matter up with Ed. Fulcher, 403-22nd Street, he could locate a suitable man.

Sincerely yours,

(Sgd.) J.E. Matthews, M.P.
MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill

Will you please note the attached letter I have received from Mr. J.E. Matthews, M.P. Kindly draft a reply for my signature.

Encl.
Ottawa,
October 27, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Mr. J.E. Matthews, M.P., recently visited the Brandon Residential School and, in a letter to the Department, states that the roof of the school requires repairs, also that there are other minor repairs required. It would, therefore, be appreciated if you would visit the school at an early date and let me know exactly what is needed. We have already expended approximately $600.00 for repairs and new equipment at this school this year. We do not appear to have any correspondence on file regarding the roof. It might be advisable, when you are visiting the school, to suggest to the Principal that such matters should be brought to your attention.

In his letter Mr. Matthews also refers to the Principal's residence. I am aware that this is in bad condition but unfortunately no heavy expenditure can be made at the present time. However, if there are minor repairs that would improve this building, the Department is prepared to consider them. I should appreciate hearing from you as soon as you have an opportunity of visiting the school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Matthews:

I am in receipt of your letter of October 16, with reference to a recent visit that you made to the Brandon Indian Residential School.

The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch are aware that a new residence for the Principal will have to be provided at some future date.

We have already expended a considerable amount at this school this summer in making minor repairs. The condition of the roof has not previously been reported to us and Inspector Hamilton is being instructed to ascertain definitely what is required. I note your recommendation regarding Mr. Ed. I am in receipt of your letter of October 16, with reference to a recent visit that you made to the Brandon Indian Residential School.

The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch are aware that a new residence for the Principal will have to be provided at some future date.

We have already expended a considerable amount at this school this summer in making minor repairs. The condition of the roof has not previously been reported to us and Inspector Hamilton is being instructed to ascertain definitely what is required. I note your recommendation regarding Mr. Ed. Fulcher, 403 - 22nd Street, Brandon.

Yours sincerely,

C.W. Jackson,
Chief Executive Assistant.

J.E. Matthews, Esq., M.P.,
Brandon, Man.

PP
Dear Sir,

As requested in your letter 133-0-5, dated October 27th, I investigated into the repairs required at the Brandon Indian School and would report as follows.

The roof does not leak at present and the repair work required should be left until the coming spring. Mr. Chapin submitted a request for this work in August 23, 1941, a copy of which was forwarded to Ottawa under cover of my letter of August 26th. Mr. Chapin gave a quotation on the work as submitted by McDowall and Duke, for the amount of $400.00. This figure covered certain repair work to the roofing, re-tarring and re-gravelling. This work as stated above should be done in the spring, otherwise if left, it may be necessary to renew the roofing and this would entail heavy expense.

The barn needs reshingling on the south side. It will require approximately forty thousand shingles. It is too late to do this work; but Mr. Chapin stated he would arrange to have the shingles put on early in the spring if the shingles and nails were supplied. He suggested the purchase be made at once, otherwise the material might not be available in the early spring. I would recommend the purchase of the shingles and nails on the distinct understanding that the labour required be provided by the Principal.

The Principal's residence is in poor condition; but the building does not justify the outlay of heavy expense. Mr. Chapin felt he could carry on for the present but pointed out that next spring new screens would be urgently needed. The old screen frames are so badly rotted they are past repairing.

I would recommend that a plumber be sent to the school to do the necessary repairs to the flush tanks - the working parts in connection with the floats are badly worn and in many cases new parts are needed. At the same time he should check all water taps and those past repairing should be replaced with spring taps, if they can be obtained. I make this recommendation because the water supply is limited and the spring taps would always be closed when not in use.

Steam radiator valves are needed on some of the radiators and this could also receive attention by the plumber and steamfitter.

The seat covers were all missing on the boys' toilets. I would recommend six new lids be provided and that these be made secure with bolts.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6257, file 576-5, part 7)
A number of beds are broken and past repairing. Ten new beds should be provided. The standard institutional bed in white is desired. I would also recommend that Mr. Chapin be instructed to send to Winnipeg for repair twenty bed springs. These springs belong to the children's beds and are so badly stretched that they form a hammock. No doubt Parkhills or some other bedding company could re-stretch the cables.

One other matter should receive attention and Mr. Chapin again offered to do the work if the required material was provided. Neither the boys or girls have any suitable place to hang their winter coats and garments. A proper place could be fixed in the basement if the following materials were provided:

- 10 pieces 2 x 4 - 12 ft. long,
- 12 doz. heavy metal hooks (with the required screws)

I hope funds can be made available to carry out the repairs suggested, all of which are much needed.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.
Ottawa,
November 18, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, with reference to your recent inspection of the Brandon Residential School.

The following expenditures are approved:

1. Plumber to repair the tanks, check water taps and replace taps that cannot be repaired, also supply steam radiator valves. It is understood that only the necessary work will be done and the cost kept as low as possible.

2. Purchase 6 new seat covers for boys' toilets.

3. You may arrange for having the bed springs repaired.

4. You may purchase the following material:
   - 10 pieces 2 x 4 - 12 ft. long
   - 12 Doz. heavy metal hooks with screws

I have noted your recommendation that the roof of the building and the south side of the barn should be reshingled next year. I am including the amount that will be required in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1943-44. We have recently been advised that it is impossible to secure shingles at the present time in the vicinity of Winnipeg. You should write to me again in connection with the shingling about April 1 at which time I will know if the amount requested in the estimates has been allowed. At that time you should give me an estimate of the cost of the new screens for the Principal's residence.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

Brandon, Man., April 26th, 1943

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Our feed grinder has completely given out. It has come to the place where the plates are so worn they will not crush the grain. We tried to set them up a little more but the machine simply gummed up. The bearings on the machine are also so badly worn that new plates could not be put on without the risk of damage to them unless the whole machine is overhauled and new bearings put in. This would cost practically the price of a new grinder, and would not be economy as the old machine is so old and shaky. I cannot find definitely when this was purchased but it goes back beyond twenty years so it has done good service. A lot of feed is put through it in a year.

I have enquired prices and received the following quotations—

International Harvester Co.
10 inch plates, plain bearings, $72.50
10½" ball bearings, $143.50

Massey Harris Co.
10½ inch plates, ball bearings, $74.75

McLeod's Ltd.
11 inch plates, ball bearings, $66.50

May I have authority to order one at once from McLeod's Ltd.? With both hogs and cattle to feed our need is rather imperative.

Our field mower has got to the place where it will not do the work any longer. Last summer we had to use the binder to finish the hay crop. Our binders are also getting
so old that we would not want to put them into the hay crop this summer.

The International Harvester Co. give a price of $100.00 for a 5 foot mower but say they have none available at present and do not know what they will be getting.

The Massey Harris Co. have two types, both available at present. One with enclosed gears running in oil, No.33, at $156.00. The other with open gears, No.37, at $120.50. McLeod's Ltd. do not handle mowers.

What are your instructions regarding the above?

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing two accounts from Yates, Neale & Co. both of which represented work which needed immediate attention.

The boys' dormitory toilet kept plugging in spite of all we could do. They took the bowl off and found the lime incrustation had almost closed the drain.

The water pump was beginning to be very slow in pumping. Leather no doubt were needed and perhaps discs. They took the pump to their shop for work on it. They found the bearings needed attention also, and while they had the pump apart gave it a thorough overhaul. It is now in first class condition.

In March frost reached the pipe line below ground between the horse barn and cow barn. They loaned us sufficient old pipe and ran a temporary line above ground which we covered with manure. This proved quite satisfactory and gave us ample water for the cow barn. We are still using the temporary line as the frost has not yet come out of the original line.

During the winter when the furnaces are going we need use only one Cottage Heater for hot water. The grates from the other heater had been used to keep this going, so with milder weather when we had to put on the other heater we were three grates short.

Trusting the above explanations of needs are satisfactory.

Yours truly,

Dr. McGill.

Re: Brandon Indian Residential School

With reference to your memorandum of July 9th last, the question of proposed repairs to the roof of this school was referred to our Engineering and Construction Service who have been in correspondence with Mr. Gow concerning it.

From Mr. Gow's report he is of opinion that the original workmanship and materials in the roof were of high quality and that by carrying out certain repairs its life may be extended for several years. These repairs, however, are somewhat more extensive than what is covered by the tender of McDowell and Doke of $340.00.

While it is considered that the only method of obtaining guaranteed freedom from future trouble is a completed new four ply felt pitch and gravel roof carrying the manufacturer's bond, such new roof is not considered essential at this time. In view of the apparent uniform and normal deterioration of the roof covering, it is recommended that the work at present be confined to:

1. Removing and replacing loose gravel, resetting and caulking metal flashings, providing new felt flashings at parapets, applying a liberal coating of pitch over the whole roof.

(over) ..........
2. The repair of the leakage, and replacement of roofing in the vicinity of the roof hopper over the southwest corner of the Assembly Hall.

3. The replacement of roofing over the room adjoining the kitchen.

These items should be undertaken at once.

It is considered that a reasonable estimate for this work is $500.00.

We would recommend that we be authorized to have Mr. Gow arrange to have the above work carried out by a reliable firm of roofers at a cost not to exceed $500.00 under supervision from his office and that $500.00 be transferred to our Engineering and Construction Service for the purpose.

We cannot undertake to say when the work could be carried out under existing circumstances, but if our recommendation is approved, Mr. Gow will be requested to do all he can to expedite operations.

[Signature]

I submit the following report on the Brandon Indian Residential School, inspected April 26th and 27th, 1944.

There are 132 pupils. The three classroom teachers are all qualified with years of experience. The classroom work is well advanced and I consider the pupils well along in their respective grades.

The Department will pay grant for 156 pupils, so at present they are 24 pupils short. At the end of June when school is closed about 15 pupils will graduate, which will then make a total shortage of around 40 pupils. The chances of recruiting for this school are not good, because the parents feel the children are not well trained, nor are they well fed. Last year the food problem was a real point of issue with many. Fortunately this has improved; but unfortunately the Indians have not forgotten.

The school was clean and the dormitories in good condition.

The Sewing Room is in charge of Miss Maguire. The children do very good work and the older girls can make most of their own clothes. The discarded army clothing is remade and used for both the boys and girls.

The laundry work is supervised by Miss Boak. I found the work well done. The plaster is falling off the walls and ceiling in several places and the wrapping around the water pipe has rotted and fallen apart. This is due, I believe, to the excessive dampness, especially in the winter. There are two ventilators in the ceiling but neither works. These should be repaired and if necessary a large electric fan installed in the side wall. The fan could be used on wash days and would carry out the moisture. The repair work mentioned should be done during the summer when most of the children are away.

Miss Cochrane is girls' supervisor, but at present is supplying in the kitchen. A new kitchen matron was expected this week. I was present when several meals were served and there appeared plenty as far as bulk is concerned. The meals consist of:

**Breakfast**
- 1 cup of milk,
- Porridge with milk and sugar
- Bread with beef dripping.

**Dinner**
- Meat Stew
- Potatoes (boiled with jackets on)
- Carrots
- Rice pudding, bread, water to drink.
Supper -
Vegetable Soup - lots of vegetables in it,
Bread spread with butter,
Prunes (changed with custards and jellies)
Tea for seniors - water for others.

I feel certain the children have plenty of food, because the bread issue is liberal and they can have more if they ask. I did, however, feel that the beef stew consisted mostly of gravy. In my opinion more meat is required. I would also recommend that hot cocoa be made with milk and served to the small children to replace the cold water. There is a large herd of cattle kept at this school and there should be enough milk for cooking, puddings, porridge and the making of cocoa. At present they get about 120 lbs. per milking, or 12 gallons per milking.

Mr. LeFevre is the engineer. He is a new member of the staff and I doubt if his services will be retained for long. A younger and more active man is required. In the children's wash rooms I found some taps not working and a number needing new washers. In view of the shortage of water the taps should all be in good repair and I told Mr. Chapin, the Principal, that he should have the engineer check these taps morning, noon and night. This would require only a few minutes and would no doubt prevent the waste of many gallons of water.

It might be advisable to dig a trench around the north side of the basin in which the water is collected with a view to striking more water. If any extra were located it could then be directed into the basin.

The plaster in the boys' playroom is broken in many places - even the V joint is split and pieces broken from the walls. Repair work to this room is urgently needed. The girls' playroom is in fair condition. Some glass is also needed for the windows.

Miss Hart is in charge of the dispensary and infirmary. At present she has a few cases of mumps, but none is very sick.

The large dairy barn measuring about 116 x 45 is in fair condition. Some glass is needed for the windows and three storm sashes are missing.

The pig pen and slaughter house measures 28 x 50. One window sash missing and 24 panes of glass. Stock barn 24 x 100, with a 34' lean. This barn needs re-shingling on the south side and the shingles have been purchased from Wade and Sons of Brandon. Eleven window sashes are missing and over 150 panes of glass needed. The interior of the barn should be thoroughly cleaned and if not used the doors should be locked.

The chicken house is 12' x 60' and in good condition. A few shingles are needed on the north side of the roof.

Machine shop measures 27' x 56'. The walls of the first story are cement and the upper part is frame.

At present the upper part is one large room and at times has been used for a gymnasium. It would make an ideal place for teaching carpentry. The building is heated from a furnace on the ground floor.

The root-house is large and in good repair. The vegetables needed to be picked over and the place thoroughly cleaned.

The ice-house was filled with ice. A portion of this building is used for storing meat. This room needed a thorough cleaning.

The manure from the stable is hauled out west of the barns near the city golf links and scattered over about half an acre of ground. If the manure is not needed now it should be put into a pile about 16 ft. wide and 6 ft. high and continued in length as required. In this way the place would look tidy and the manure would heat and later be useful on the land. I pointed this out to the new stockman, Mr. Haggerty, and in time I am sure he will try to improve the situation.

The Principal's house is in poor condition and I doubt if extensive repairs could be justified.

House No. 2 is occupied by Mr. Haggerty. The walk leading to the house should be renewed. The plaster is badly cracked on some rooms. This should be repaired and the walls and ceiling re-tinted.

House No. 3 is used by the farming instructor, Mr. Udell. This house should be painted. On the east side the old paint has almost entirely disappeared. Painting and papering is also needed inside.

House No. 4 is a very old building. It is leased for $10.00 a month to a man who works at the Experimental Farm. The house is well cared for and the present renters have made many repairs.

Mr. Chapin, the Principal, has found the question of discipline difficult to handle and tells me he is leaving at the end of June. In March some of the boys and girls got out of the dormitories at night and on one occasion the girls were away two nights before being found. They were hiding in one of the root cellars at the rear of the barn. The girls let themselves down from the third storey dormitory by tying the bed sheets together. I understand they may have escaped about 1 a.m. after the staff had retired. The boys, with the exception of one from Norway House, were immediately discharged. The Norway House boy will be sent home when navigation opens.

The Church authorities in selecting a new Principal should make sure they have a man who can enforce discipline and is accustomed to the supervision of others. It is difficult to get a suitable staff and they, almost as much as the children, need constant supervision. The Principal needs to be active, alert and continually checking. To get the school back into good shape means hard work.
and only a man willing to work should be recommended.

I would like authority to spend $150.00 to do the following repair work:

1. Purchase 10 gals. of barn paint and small quantity of oil.
2. Purchase glass.
3. Purchase some lumber to repair doors, etc.
4. Purchase water taps and other plumbing repairs.

The work should be done at once and authority for the expenditure would be appreciated.

In closing I would like to state that in my opinion neither the Brandon nor the Elkhorn Schools receive sufficient supervision. I would recommend that both schools be attached to the Griswold Agency and that Mr. Young be instructed to make monthly inspections and submit reports through this office. In this way recommendations can be followed up and certain work pushed to completion.

"We have had trouble with the septic tank of the bungalow. It plugged up entirely and backed up into the cellar. Nobody knew where the septic tank was exactly, as it was covered over and sodded. Mr. Yates brought out the Provincial Inspector, and he says we will have to have a cement bottom put into it to meet requirements. RE: Brandon School

I spent yesterday with Mr. Strapp at the Brandon School. Already he has made several improvements; but there is much to do yet.

I would recommend that the following expenditures be given consideration:

1. The Principal's Residence needs interior decorations. Already Mr. Strapp has had the plaster repaired in the various rooms and the walls are really for papering. It will cost from $250 to $300 to do the necessary work (papering and painting), and even then part of the house will be closed off and not used. Authority for this expenditure should be granted at once.

2. The shingles for the one barn have never been put on. Labour will be required and the cost may reach $150. At present the barn is practically useless and the rain is rotting the floors, etc. If labor is obtainable the work should be done now.

3. New stoneworking is required. The water runs down along the foundation and if allowed to continue will ruin the foundation.

4. The upright boiler Mr. Strapp claims has not sufficient steam capacity, and as the result it takes four days to wash what should be done in a day. Mr. Strapp thinks a second upright boiler should be supplied. However, this is a matter which might be carried over until after the war.

Already, authority has been granted for the following:

(Cont'd)
1. $150 for glass, paint, plumbing, repairs and lumber. This total will be accounted for by Mr. Strapp.

2. Repairs to laundry walls and ventilators: may involve from $75 to $100.

3. Purchase of electric fan for laundry; this to draw the moisture out.

4. Repairs to Syptic tank at cottage; approximately $200.

5. Repair to Syptic tank manholes at School--this requires considerable excavation and cement work and may cost $75 or $100.

Mr. Strapp is apparently a hard worker. I believe if he remains he will in due course bring the school back to its old high standing. We must, however, spend some money on repair work. It cannot all be done this fall, but we have listed the more essential things and I hope Mr. Strapp will be encouraged by receiving instructions to proceed with the repairs listed.

A. G. Hamilton

Re: Brandon Indian School.

I was again at the Brandon School on January 8th and would report as follows.

Your authority for $150.00, file 123-0-5, dated May 17th, Mr. Strapp states has been used except for a few cents.

Authority in your letter, 123-0-5, dated May 17th for:
1. Repair to ventilators - work completed.
2. Purchase of electric fan - not obtainable here, but should be installed when obtainable, in upper half of window.
3. The plaster has been repaired.

Authority in your letter, 123-0-5, dated June 29th,
1. Repair to septic tank at bungalow completed and vouchers sent in.
2. Manholes repaired and manhole covers provided for school septic tank. Instructed Yates to supply Mr. Strapp at once with necessary invoice.

The shingles have not yet been put on the barn. Mr. Strapp was unable to get help. I interviewed a Mr. Robinson of Kenton, and he will try to do the work before March 10th. If by chance the weather remains too cold, and the work cannot be done I would like authority to purchase 500 tamarack posts. These are available now at Wades Lumber Company, at 3½¢ for 4" tops and 2½¢ for 6" tops. The fences are in very poor condition and must be repaired during the coming summer.

The houses all need exterior painting. Mr. Strapp states he cannot undertake the work and to date he has not been able to get anyone to even submit a quotation.

The folding chairs supplied for the auditorium or chapel are in poor condition; in fact, many are out of use and others are unsafe and should be discarded. This was brought to the Department's attention some months ago, but at that time apparently funds were not available. Now a strong folding chair can be obtained from the Stony Mountain Penitentiary priced at $2.75 each. I enclose a letter from Warden Campbell dealing with this matter.

I inspected the Brandon Indian School, May 16th, 1945.

The children appear in excellent health and are, I am sure, receiving plenty of well prepared food.

The school building was clean, and the dormitories tidy. Several repairs have been made to the doors, windows and walls so that conditions have greatly improved.

The one stock barn is in a disgraceful condition. Mr. Strapp has been unable to have this barn shingled because he could not get help. In addition to the roof, new doors should be provided - the windows repaired and refit - corner boards and siding repaired where required, and all patch work painted. Then Mr. Strapp wants a poultry house made upstairs in the lean-to which faces south. He needs this extra room because more poultry should be kept. I would recommend that the Department, or that Mr. Strapp be instructed to call for tenders from contract firms to do the work outlined. I am convinced this is the only way the work will be accomplished. As stated above, the barn is in a disgraceful condition and I feel we should spend the amount necessary to save a barn which to erect now would cost from $6000.00 to $8000.00. If left in its present condition it will soon become worthless.

After this barn is repaired I would recommend the Department advise Mr. Strapp that he should see to it that the barn is kept in good repair. I would not be surprised if the material and labor would cost over $1000.00. The barn is needed and as stated above, we cannot afford longer to neglect this much needed repair.

Another matter that must not be neglected longer is the repair needed to the eavestroughing. All three barns should have new eavestroughing on the north side. There are barns here and the water runs off the roof down along the stone foundation and is undermining the foundation. On the south side the water can get away and does not affect the foundation. I understand McDowell and Duke, Brandon, can now supply the material and are prepared to do the work, but if some of the old material is to be used and repaired, they cannot very well submit a quotation.

The Principal's house needs the eavestroughing repaired and parts renewed. This work should be done at the same time as the barn. The entire bottom is rusted out of some of the eavestroughing and this repair work is absolutely necessary.

I would further recommend that Mr. Strapp be requested to call for tenders to do the following painting:

1. The farmer's house just inside the main entrance should be painted. It is in bad condition - two coats will help but it is really a three coat job.

2. The Principal's residence should have one coat of paint.
3. The cottage between the school and Principal's residence requires two coats of shingle paint.

Here again this repair work will entail expense but it is useless for me or anyone else to make repeated inspections and expect to see improvements unless funds can be provided for the work. We are hardly faced with the initial cost of putting these schools in good condition but we must realize that a yearly expenditure, and of a considerable amount, must be provided; otherwise, they cannot be maintained as a government institution should. To be advised that six or eight hundred dollars is allowed for Brandon, or Elkhorn, or Birtle, or any large assembly of buildings, and that this may be used where most urgently needed, and the balance must wait for the next fiscal year, just isn't good enough. We have these institutions, and while we have them we should provide the necessary funds to keep them maintained so that the Principal, staff and pupils, as well as the Government, may be justly proud of the institution. I urge that the recommendations outlined be carried out and at once. I will be away most of the summer so that instructions should be sent direct to Mr. Strapp, with a copy for my file.

The Government sign just inside the school gate is, I consider, past repairing, and Mr. Strapp should be instructed to have it removed. It would be more credit to the Government not to have any than to leave the bleached, faded and broken one now in use.

I should add that the new steam ironer had just arrived and will be installed within the next few days. I am sure this equipment will lighten greatly the work in the laundry department and so will be greatly appreciated.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

Your attention is especially directed to the report on the upright high pressure boiler used for the laundry.
