As originally designed and installed in 1929 the water supply system at this school was quite simple and except in case of fire the operation was automatically controlled. It was realized that the quantity of water available from the reservoir was limited and conservation of water would be necessary. Of the estimated daily usage of 5,000 gallons, about 4,000 gallons were supplied by gravity to the barns, kitchens, laundry, children's showers and toilets, the boilers and hot water heaters. The other services on the main floor and the floors above were supplied through the pressure tank system. This system consisted of a 2 H.P. motor direct connected on the same shaft to a 1,000 g.p.m. typhoon pump connected with a 1,200 gallon pressure tank which ordinarily supplied water to the services at pressure varying from 40 lbs. to 80 lbs; the operation of the pump being controlled by automatic pressure regulator. An air compressor was installed to maintain the required air pressure in the tank and safety valves were also included. The 15 H.P. Motor driven centrifugal pump was installed for fire and emergency use only.

The system worked very well until 1939 when the lessening water supply necessitated the tapping of an auxiliary water supply and in 1940 a pipe line was laid from a newly constructed reservoir at a higher spring some 1,500 feet distant. This new work was not laid out or constructed by this office and we are not familiar with the alteration made in connection with the water supply services. It appears, however, that this upper reservoir supplied a gravity head of about 25 lbs. pressure and so eliminated the necessity for pump operation entirely and the piping was changed accordingly. This necessitated the installation of several more valves throughout the water system and as long as water supply met the water demand the system was very satisfactory. It would also appear that with the advent of the complete gravity system the use of water increased and the pumping installation was permitted to deteriorate.

During the past winter and probably during the past two or three winters there were times when the demand for water exceeded the supply and the pressure became inadequate to supply services. To overcome this deficiency the school management had to fall back on the water supply of the lower reservoir and pumping had to be resorted to. The Typhoon Pump was out of order and the large pump had to be operated without benefit of automatic control. To maintain a water supply all night under these conditions would have necessitated the engineer remaining on the job. The failure of the water supply referred to by the present Principal of the school was a result of the method of operation rather than from any shortage of water in the reservoirs. The many valves in the system, while apparently placed of necessity, rather added to the difficulty of operation when a switch from the gravity supply to pumping became necessary.

T. S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering and Construction Service,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.
The situation at the school was investigated on two occasions this summer by engineers from this office. Both visits happened to follow heavy rains and the water supply was abundant with overflow from the springs forming little streams. There have been staff changes and the present staff is conversant only with conditions as existed last winter. It is difficult to understand the complaints as to shortage of water at night with the gravity system—a period of low usage of water. With severe frosty nights there may have been sufficient lowering of pressure to affect the water supply on the top storey of the building. Whatever the trouble it is desirable that it be eliminated and that the pumping operations be made as inexpensive, simple and automatic as possible.

The water supply system in the school worked satisfactorily from 1929 to 1939 and it is proposed to return to that system in principle. The basement distribution system which includes the barns and outside services will be supplied by gravity from both the high and low reservoirs at pressures of about 25 lbs. and 6½ lbs., respectively. Water will flow from the lower reservoir only when the supply fails from the upper reservoir. The other floors of the building will be supplied by a pressure system varying from 30 lbs. to 60 lbs., through the pressure tank and supplied by pumping from the gravity supply. The use of water at the school is estimated by the Principal to be about 13,000 gallons daily which appears to be a high rate of usage. However, about 50% of this usage will be supplied by gravity.

The Principal of the School has suggested that a 2,000 gallon per hour pump be installed and the system of valves simplified. The 1,000 g.p.h. pump now installed needs thorough overhauling and probably replacement, although I believe $60.00 was recently spent upon the motor. If the pump has to be replaced it is suggested that a 1,000 g.p.h. pump is adequate but as pumping noises have always caused complaints in the school, a 2,000 g.p.h. pump should reduce the periods of annoyance 50%. A new pressure switch must be installed. The use of the large pump must be limited to fire and emergency use. It appears that the small pump is now utilized to feed water to the high pressure steam boiler. If such is the case the practice should be discontinued and the high pressure steam boiler fed from the source originally connected to.

Recommendations:

It is recommended that the Typhoon Pump be removed and be examined by a competent machinist to determine whether it should be completely overhauled or replaced and his advice be acted upon. The water distribution system should be altered so as to restore the original idea of having all services above the main basement floor supplied by a pressure tank system. Unnecessary valves should be removed and check valves installed where necessary to provide the combined gravity and pressure system. The whole distribution system should be thoroughly gone over to eliminate the present excessive leakage and waste of water. Provision should be made for using the large centrifugal pump in the system but only as a standby for water supply and for fire protection.

We are unable to give any reasonable estimate of the probable cost of carrying out the work involved in the above outlined suggestions. The work involved is more or less in the nature of maintenance work and the extent of the work will be governed to a considerable degree by what is discovered as the job progresses.

(Sgd.) D.B. Gow,
District Chief Engineer.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

I am sorry that it has not been possible to get contractors to carry out the repairs authorized during recent months. I also regret very much that I personally accepted any responsibility for attempting to have the repairs made, as it has simply been a headache during the past year and I am very little further ahead.

I was in touch with the contractors for the eavestroughing on Tuesday last and they were not even civil about the matter. They just informed me that when they were able to get the material they would do the job, but at present all supplies were taken up by Wartime Housing, and if Indian Affairs wanted the work done they must supply a 'Priority Rating'.

I am enclosing a tender submitted by Mr. F. Young for the painting but Mr. Young informs me that as the eavestroughing has not been done and the season is late this work should not be done until next April. I beg to suggest that this tender be held in abeyance until the early part of the next fiscal year.

The matter of replacing of glass in the windows is simply one of time. It should really have been done before I accepted any responsibility for the school. I have had the men doing as much repair work as possible in addition to their regular work at the school. To date about 150 panes of glass have been replaced, repairs have been carried out to the cement floors in the barns, window frames and doors have been repaired, and at the very time of Mr. Hamilton's visit Mr. Osborne of our staff had the glass for the windows in the hog pen and in the course of a day or so these panes of glass were all in the frames.
With reference to the "weeds and grass" even Dr. Doyle found it quite a problem to keep these under control when I visited this school in 1936. At that time there was a fairly large group of senior boys who could be trusted with a scythe. I spoke to our farm instructor about the matter and he advised that it would be wise to burn this off rather than attempt to use mowers as already they had broken a mower tongue on one of the many stumps that are only just above ground. I will see that this is attended to as soon as possible.

I quite agree that there are a number of things about this school that make it appear "as if no one was very much interested in it," and this goes back for quite a number of years. However that does not help us today. I am definitely interested and I am sure that you too are interested, but it will take time and money to repair the neglect of the past. I am wondering whether the windows, sashes and frames, have been painted since the building was built in 1929? If this matter is not attended to in the near future it will be necessary to make repairs to the woodwork.

I am very much of the opinion that this school should be visited by a competent authority, a careful survey made of the requirements and a program of repairs planned over several years to put the buildings in first class order, and thereafter a definite program of upkeep should be adopted.

This year has been one of extreme difficulty, particularly in the matter of the administration of discipline. I was very much encouraged on my visits to many of the reservations by the kindly attitude and the very evident interest of so many of the parents toward, and in the school. I believe that there is a real trend toward higher standards of education, particularly along vocational lines, amongst many of the Saskatchewan and Manitoba Indians and hope that with the close of the war it will be possible to obtain the necessary equipment and instructors to carry on this type of training.

I remain,

Yours truly,

It is therefore recommended, that to remedy the unsatisfactory high pressure steam and hot water supply at the school, consideration should be given to:

(a) Removal of the existing 10 H.P. vertical type high pressure steam boiler, together with the two jacket heaters, and the water heating coils now in use, removing the hot water load entirely from the low pressure heating system. After being thoroughly cleaned, it is assumed that the existing storage tanks will be satisfactory.

(b) Installing a horizontal, firebox type, return tubular high pressure boiler of approximately 50 H.P. capacity with mechanical stoker, pressure reducing valve, new indirect steam hot water heater, condensation pump, the necessary new piping and other standard accessories, as well as building an additional flue on the existing chimney.

By the suggested remodelling operations, ample high pressure steam and hot water could be made available from one source; a number of units of outworn equipment soon needing repairs or replacement would be eliminated, and a considerable saving of fuel would be possible.

The estimated cost of the suggested remodelling, including materials, labour, contingencies and supervision, would be in the neighborhood of $6800.00.

If our recommendation is approved, drawings and specifications should be prepared by this Service, on the basis of a thorough examination of the whole system by an officer from Ottawa.

Chief Engineer.

Memorandum:

Re: Brandon Indian Residential School.

In connection with Mr. Hoey's memorandum of May 23rd, 1946 and your notations of the 28th instant thereon and further to our memorandum of February 25th, 1946, you are advised as follows:

Our Mr. Hargreaves was sent to Brandon on June 16th, 1946, to obtain technical data in order that a layout and specification might be prepared for this work.

Summarized, it can be stated that after a thorough inspection of the design and installed equipment in the laundry and domestic hot water services, extensive alterations and replacements are vitally necessary if these services are to function normally. Much of the equipment is worn out and the piping installation is of very poor design.

Going into some detail it can be stated that:

The high pressure steam boiler is badly rusted and in operation is greatly overloaded. It is a 10 horsepower unit which was originally intended to serve the tumbler dryer, and laundry only, which in themselves require 12 horsepower, steam at 100 lbs. per square inch. Of late, due to an almost total lack of hot water, this boiler has been used to heat water in the washing machine which adds approximately 10 horsepower. In view of the above load and the fact that the safety valve setting to 80 lbs. per square inch is obvious that the boiler cannot be operated safely. No means for replacing loss by evaporation to the boiler is provided, the boiler being the only method of heating.

Boiler pressure fluctuated from 70 to 100 lbs. per square inch and could not be kept constant under normal and sudden demands.

It was found that an Indian lad aged 15 years was employed to tend the boiler for periods up to 2 hours, while the boiler maker was engaged on other duties. Such responsibilities should not be placed upon the Department open to censure in case of a fatal accident.

The domestic hot water storage tank has been badly rusted. It was found to be very thin in places and pitted. It is our opinion that the tank is intended to be heated by an electric heater connected to both the hot water service and to a jacket heater for the boiler. The heater is badly rusted and sealed.

For the service intended this heater should have been a steam fed type. The connections between the heater and tank are poorly made as are the connections between the jacket heater and tank.

The jacket heater is badly scaled and is in very poor shape. A 200 gallon tank with a submerged steam fed coil serves the upper floor and is apparently giving satisfaction. The jacket heater serving this tank in summer is in bad shape. Connections between the jacket heater and tank are poorly made.

3. The low pressure heating boilers are in need of some repairs and a good cleaning, and can be expected to give further service if reasonable care and attention is given them. Grates should be replaced in one unit and the covering should be replaced. The steam connections in the boiler room are not too bad except that the covering has deteriorated badly.

Recommendation:

In view of the fact that the high pressure boiler, the indirect heater, the jacket heaters and 1000 gallon storage tank are unfit for further service, and totally unable to cope with the demand, it is recommended that the plant be modernized and brought up to date so that trouble free service will be available.

Since the domestic hot water load and the high pressure steam requirements nearly balance the building heating load, it is recommended that one new steel portable high pressure steam boiler of 40 horse-power be installed to handle all high pressure steam services and to heat all domestic hot water for the entire building. A stoker should be provided for this boiler along with an automatic boiler feed pump and cold water replacement regulator, plus all standard boiler fittings.

One low pressure heating boiler should be scrapped and the remaining boiler thoroughly cleaned, fitted with new grates and re-covered. This boiler when discarded from the domestic hot water service will be capable of handling the building heating load except under most adverse weather conditions, under which circumstances the high pressure boiler can be made to help out by a connection through a pressure reducing valve to the low pressure header.

Should it be necessary at some time in the future to make further repairs to the low pressure boiler, the new high pressure boiler would have sufficient capacity to carry the heating load temporarily at relatively small sacrifice to the domestic hot water and laundry service.

A new 1000 gallon storage tank with a self contained regulating valve should be installed with an indirect steam fed heater of 500 gallons per hour capacity. The 200 gallon tank can be retained but its submerged coil should be connected to the high pressure boiler load.

Steam connections to the tank heaters should be made from the low pressure header.

Both jacket heaters should be dispensed with.

The estimated cost for this work installed is $7000.00

Should our recommendations be approved and authority issued to proceed with the work, we recommend that it be carried out on the basis of data and instructions prepared in this office, with supervision supplied by Mr. Gow. We feel that it would be difficult to obtain a lump sum tender from a contractor, and consider that Mr. Gow should be authorized to obtain materials and skilled tradesmen to the best advantage locally.

   This stove has had minor repairs on a number of occasions but will now need to be replaced as the interior baffles have burned out and the oven plates are very thin. The canopy is in good shape and will not have to be replaced.

2. Steam heating plant, low and high pressure:
   The low pressure boilers to which are connected the hot water supply tanks are not in very good shape as the shells have been patched on a number of occasions. Both boilers need retubing as small leaks have developed which indicate that the tubes are pitting. The heating system for the pupils hot water supply does not function satisfactorily necessitating the carrying of hot water for the pupils bathing from the staff supply on the main floor. The two auxiliary jacket heaters are not able to cope with the demand for hot water at any time.

   The high pressure boiler for the laundry has deteriorated in the head with the result that the constant movement with the expansion and contraction of the head causes the tubes to become loose from time to time thus causing leaks at the tube ends. I doubt whether this boiler will pass another inspection without the effective steam pressure being reduced. This will mean loss of efficiency in our drying and flatwork ironing machines.

over.
The Secretary.

Indian Affairs Branch.

The Engineering & Surveys Branch, Winnipeg, has made a complete survey of the pump room and the boiler room and no doubt have a complete report on the matter. It is imperative that this matter be considered as soon as possible.

3. The whole of the interior of the school should be painted, particularly the pupils quarters. This could be done in units from time to time.

4. The class rooms need redecoration and attention should be paid to the lighting, especially of the two rooms with northern exposure. The present system of electric lighting is not good and I would suggest that the new system of fluorescent lighting be installed.

5. There is not any provision for seating or lockers in the basement play rooms for the pupils. I would recommend that a type of box-seat-locker be provided. This could be done by the senior boys as soon as material is available, as a manual training project after school opens.

The seating in the assembly room is very inadequate, there being only 75 seats available for pupils and staff. It is necessary to carry benches from the pupils' dining room up to the assembly hall with the resultant wrecking of the benches and frequent damage to the plaster in the halls. A large number of these chairs have been repaired, but we should have at least another 75 new ones.

I believe that Mr. Inspector Hamilton of Winnipeg could secure a suitable chair, through the warden of the penitentiary, at a reasonable price.

6. The barns are in very poor condition. #1. Horse barn; Roof needs re-shingling on south side and considerable repairs to the north side. #2 Dairy barn; roof needs re-shingling and possible replacement of sheeting in several places. #3 Hog pen; Roof needs repairs to sheeting and re-shingling. All these buildings need repairs to outside sheeting and painting.

#4 Barn is in serious condition and should be wrecked and the materials used to build a good hog pen, poultry house, and granary. There is sufficient material to frame all these buildings and have sufficient for the framing of a manual training shop.

I respectfully beg to suggest again (ref letter Oct.19,1945) that "this school should be visited by a competent authority."

"a careful survey made of the requirements, and a program of repairs planned over several years to put the buildings in first class order. That thereafter a definite program of upkeep should be adopted."

May I say that I shall be only too pleased to co-operate with Indian Affairs Officials as far as possible in this matter.

I remain,

Memorandum, August 20th, 1946.

Re: Indian Residential School, Brandon, Manitoba

In connection with Mr. Healy's memorandum of August 9th, 1946 and your notations of the 13th instant thereon, you are advised as follows:

Your attention is directed to our memorandum to you of July 29th, 1946 in which the necessary work to put this plant on an efficient operating basis, is outlined.

Due to the inter-dependence of each unit in the boiler room, one to the other, it is most difficult to utilize as small an amount as $1000.00 - $1500.00 to the best advantage in making revisions as may be part of a future design. In the complete revision, several items, all relatively costly are needed. These items include a new high pressure boiler, new indirect heater, new domestic hot water storage tank, new jacket heaters, with piping and valves and other smaller accessories.

To get the greatest value for the funds available, it will be necessary to complete one phase of the work, and after thoroughly considering the matter, such funds as are available should be spent on improvements to the domestic hot water supply system.

It is therefore recommended that the following operations be undertaken, as the first phase of the revisions.

(a) Provide one new indirect steam fed heater having a steel shell and copper tube removable element.

(b) Provide one new 1000 gallon domestic hot water storage tank.

(c) Provide one new self contained regulator valve.

(d) Provide all necessary piping and valves to complete the connections. Drawings will be prepared by this Service outlining the hook-up. The heater, regulator valve and tank, necessary components of the complete scheme, would remain undisturbed except for revisions to piping, at a time when the remaining new items of equipment are provided. This phase of the work will obviate the necessity of introducing live steam to the laundry washer from the high pressure boiler, thereby eliminating one dangerous practice now being followed.

Freed of its domestic hot water demand, the existing high pressure boiler might be nursed along to serve with partial efficiency, the demands of the laundry equipment. It is emphasized however, that this Service does not assume any responsibility for the safety of the high pressure boiler, during its operation under present conditions.

SPECIFICATION FOR NEW DOMESTIC HOT WATER EQUIPMENT

1. SCOPE OF WORK:
This specification and the accompanying plans are intended to provide for a complete set up of new domestic hot water equipment which is to be located in the existing boiler room. The Contractor shall take all measurements at the building, set out all work and be responsible for the accuracy of same. He shall provide all labour, transportation, material and plant and give his personal and constant attention to the work and be responsible for any damage done to other work incidental to the execution of his own.

2. VISIT THE SITE:
The Contractor must visit the site and thoroughly acquaint himself with the conditions under which the work will be done and govern himself accordingly.

3. MATERIALS AND WORKMANSHIP:
All materials shall be new and the best of their respective kinds, sound and free from defects.

Workmanship shall be of the best and all work shall be done in a neat manner with due attention being given to the grading of pipes and making connections. All connections shall be made so as to permit free and unobstructed flow at all times and adequate provision shall be made for expansion.

4. PIPING:
All steam and return piping used in this

Work shall be standard black steel pipe put together with cast iron screwed fittings. All pipe shall be carefully reamed before assembly and pipe compound shall be applied to pipe threads only.

5. **DOMESTIC HOT WATER TANK AND SUPPORTS:**

Disconnect and remove existing domestic hot water tank and store where directed, on the job. Provide new black steel storage tank 48" diameter by 12'-0" long, having 1/4" shell and 5/16" heads and built from 75 pounds per square inch working pressure. Both heads shall be convex, and a standard manhole shall be provided in the far end of tank as noted on plan. New tank shall be mounted on existing steel supports. Tank shall be tapped to receive all connections as outlined on drawings.

Provide and erect on suitable steel brackets where shown on plan, one new indirect gravity type domestic hot water heater. This heater shall be of standard construction, consisting of steel shell, cast iron water box and 3/4" copper tube removable element, built for maximum pressure of 100 lbs. per square inch. This heater shall have capacity to raise 850 Imperial gallons per hour from 40°F. to 140°F. when fed with steam at 0 lbs. per sq. inch. This unit shall be equal to Powers No. 11 Indicating Regulator. Provide valve by-pass including reducers as shown.

I was at Brandon School September 27, and inspected the range. It is a heavy duty Gurney Oxford No.13CL. There are three ovens with a fire box at one end of the range. The one firebox is supposed to heat the three ovens.

The Principal's residence at this school is a very old building and the old furnace had been in use for many years. The Principal was able to secure a furnace in stock from McDowell and Doke and he arranged for its immediate installation.

Under the circumstances, it is recommended that purchase order be issued so that the account may be paid. The Brandon School and Principal's Residence is Government property. The coding is as follows:- 576-76-09-622.

MEMORANDUM:

Re: Brandon Indian Residential School

Further to our memorandum of November 23rd, 1946, you are advised that we are in receipt of additional correspondence from Mr. Gow, under date of December 10th, 1946, in which he informs us of a reluctance on the part of the School Principal to have that phase of the work already approved by Indian Affairs carried out this winter, as he feels that considerable disturbance would be created and that the interference to the normal school routine would be troublesome.

In this connection, the following excerpt is quoted from Mr. Gow's letter dated the 10th instant on the matter:

"In discussing the situation at the Brandon Indian School with the Principal, I found that he was fairly well satisfied with the present hot water situation at the School and would much prefer that no action be taken this winter with respect to this installation. It is his idea that, if work of major repairs is to be carried out next summer, that this repair work can be well delayed until that time. In view of the reluctance of these firms to proceed with this installation along the lines outlined, and the wishes of the Principal of the School, we will not take any further action with respect to the matter until we have had a further communication with you on the subject."

It is felt that a brief summary of the entire project should be brought to the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch before our commentary is added, and the following outlines in condensed form, the reasons for our previous recommendations.

From October 30th, 1945, to February 9th, 1946, complaints, reports, and suggestions were submitted by the School authorities and Mr. Gow's office, all relative to the continuing inefficiencies, failures and general unsatisfactory performance of the existing high pressure steam and domestic hot water services. These conditions were confirmed by an officer from this Service on an inspection made last June. The highlights which should be kept in mind are (1) an inadequate supply of hot water due to several causes, mainly the wearing out of present equipment, (2) the inability of the high pressure boiler to provide steam at sufficient pressure and in sufficient quantity to serve the laundry machines, caused by its deterioration and excessive loads.

Our original recommendation, under date of July 29th, 1946, provided for a complete modernization of this plant, including a new high pressure boiler, sufficient in capacity to

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

handle laundry machinery and a rather large domestic hot water load. The auxiliary equipment necessary to complete this project was included along with an estimate. Indian Affairs not realizing the extent of the work involved, could not see their way clear to provide funds as estimated, and suggested that one phase of the work be carried out at this time, namely, (our recommendation), improvements to the domestic hot water service. We realize that by splitting the work up into two or more phases the cost would be increased because when the final phase is undertaken certain changes and adjustments would be necessary, disturbing to some extent, the new work. In view of the serious shortage of hot water, it was felt that, in spite of this probability, the first operation should be carried out.

In commenting on the Principal's reluctance to have part of the work done now, during the School season, we wish to say that we fully realize that the disturbance unavoidably created would tend to upset, in varying degrees, the normal school routine. We would certainly prefer having all the work carried out at one time, since a much more satisfactory solution would result.

However, due to the time required by Contractors to assemble data for their tenders, and their reluctance to take on new work at this time, any benefit that may have been derived from carrying out one phase of the work has been lost, and it would appear that nothing better could be achieved before the close of the present fiscal year, than the purchase of as much essential equipment as possible from funds now available.

If Indian Affairs concur, we will prepare a bill of materials for equipment to the approximate value of funds now transferred to this Service, for delivery to the School this fiscal year. This procedure, of course, would require a revised design and specifications embodying the completed work to be undertaken in the 1947-48 fiscal year.

Dear Mr. Glen,

I dislike troubling you, but duty compels me to bring to your attention the condition of dwelling occupied by the Superintendent or Residential School at Brandon. This matter has been before the Department, to my knowledge, at least ten years and I feel that the time has come when action will have to be taken. The house is in such a condition that further neglect of the situation could not be considered. In saying this, I am mindful of the fact that your term as Minister has been brief and that you could not be expected to have many similar matters taken care of in a short time, especially under present conditions. I want that clearly understood.

If you could have the opportunity at any time to visit this home for yourself, you would agree that my remarks concerning it are most moderate.

I cannot see that the present building in its dilapidated condition would be worth repairing. I think it would be cheaper and better in the end to have a new building.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Water Supply - Brandon Residential School, Manitoba.

Referring to your notation on copy of a memorandum from Indian Affairs dated March 11th, we have now received a report from Mr. Gow on the water situation at the above school.

Duplicate copies of this report dated March 25th are attached. You will note that the difficulty experienced has been overcome by more careful organization of the available supply from the two sources. Mr. Gow, however, points out that the water supply is diminishing and suggests that investigations proceed with a view to obtaining a water supply from the City of Brandon or from the Assiniboine River when the present supply is reduced below the needs of the school.

As water resources over the southern sections of Western Canada appear to be generally decreasing, we would concur with Mr. Gow's recommendation that steps be taken to find out if water can be obtained from the City of Brandon and at what cost. If the scheme should be feasible the matter of sharing the cost with the Experimental Farm could be considered. If water cannot be obtained at suitable cost from Brandon, the Assiniboine River scheme could be investigated.

Encl.

Director,

WINNIPEG, March 25, 1947.

Re: Water Supply, Brandon Indian Residential School - Brandon, Manitoba.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of March 14th with reference to the above mentioned subject and asking for a report on the reported partial failure of the water supply at the school. We had not intended making any report on the matter but in view of the inquiry from the Indian Affairs Branch it has been considered advisable to report upon the inspection carried out by this office.

This office was advised of the telephone message to Mr. Hamilton regarding the water supply and later, on March 4th, the Rev. Mr. Strapp called at this office in connection with the matter. Mr. Rose, an engineer of this staff, visited the school later and made certain studies with respect to the water supply situation. He found that the lower spring, which normally supplies dormitories and farm buildings, also the basement and ground floor of the school by gravity, had early in January proved insufficient to meet the demand. An examination of the reservoir by the engineer of the school showed that it was empty and he accordingly opened the by-pass valve and allowed water from the upper spring reservoir to discharge back into the lower spring reservoir so that the gravity feed to the above mentioned services was almost immediately restored. However, this discharge was permitted to continue for an hour and forty minutes, thus depleting the upper reservoir and cutting off the gravity water supply to the two upper storeys of the school. Undoubtedly, much water was wasted through the lower reservoir during the hour and forty-minute period. To supply the upper floors the motor-driven pump had to be put into operation and the upper floors supplied through the pressure tank. However, the next day water supply had been built up in the upper reservoir and the gravity system was again in operation throughout. Since then the system has been operated without inconvenience but once weekly it is necessary to permit water to flow back into the lower reservoir from the upper reservoir for about forty minutes. It is found that this procedure does not deplete the supply in the upper reservoir but does augment the supply sufficiently in the lower reservoir to permit continuous supply for one week.

Admittedly, this is not a very dependable water supply but it has proven adequate to meet the present demand. During the past few years there have been critical periods as regard the water supply from these two widely separated springs and while normally the whole system is a gravity supply, a pumping system has to be maintained for fire protection and for such an emergency as happened recently. The equipment is available for meeting the emergency created by failure of supply from either reservoir but due to changes in personnel at the school, the procedure to be followed in such emergencies is not always understood, and some confusion results.

However, there is no equipment available for providing a water supply in the event of failure of both springs. There used to be several springs in the vicinity of the school - there are now only the two with any flow and they appear to be producing less water and at critical times only careful operation permits of a water supply being maintained over such periods. The Dominion Experimental Farm, which adjoins the school property, have had similar experiences and

T. S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,

Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

now also have to meet water shortages and dwindling supply from springs on their property. The Experimental Farm has made attempts to secure water from deep wells with indifferent success and the water has not been satisfactory. There would appear to be only two alternatives open to these two Government Enterprises to secure a dependable water supply - they can either connect up with the City of Brandon water system or construct their own pumping plant with the Assiniboine River as a source of water. Either alternatives would involve a large capital outlay but in view of the threatened failure of water supply at both sites, it would appear advisable to investigate these two alternatives.

With reference to the proposed new residence for the principal at this school, I regret very much that the proposed house is of the two full storey type. This type of house has long been considered unsuitable for this climate and is not being built by any of the contractors at present doing business in Brandon.

I beg to submit a set of plans for a semi-bungalow type of residence which for this climate has a number of decided advantages in the matter of low wind resistance, good floor space, adequate lighting, and ease of heating.

This semi-bungalow type is used entirely for the larger one family residences on the Experimental Farm next door to our school farm and is highly recommended by their service bureau for the prairie climate.

These plans are VERY MUCH in the rough and would need some working over by an architect but they will give some idea of the type of building that would fit in best with the surroundings at the present site.

I would strongly recommend wrecking the present building for the material that can be obtained, as there will be enough joists, scantling, and rough lumber available to almost frame and rough sheet a semi bungalow type of house. This would not only make a saving in costs of new material but would give us well seasoned lumber as well. Should Indian Affairs decide to wreck the present building at once, I can make arrangements for living quarters and storage of extra furniture during the period until the new residence is ready.

I shall be glad to render any assistance possible in the matter of arranging for wrecking etc. that you may require.

I remain, Yours truly,

Oliver B. Strapp,
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I was at Brandon May 13th in connection with the new residence being authorized for the Principal, Mr. Strapp. I consulted the following contractors:

Higgins & Sons - now engaged in the Wartime Housing Program
Lissaman & Spratling
Mr. Walter Erickson, who represents the Pearson Bros., Winnipeg

The first two will consider the work on a cost plus basis but due to the shortage of finishing lumber and nails could not promise when the work might be completed.

Mr. Erickson stated his firm would quote either on a cost plus basis or on a complete job. He thought it might even be possible to quote on wrecking the old house and using as much of the material as possible and make the wrecking a part of the entire quotation. He claimed that at the present time he was sure his firm was in a position, should their quotation be accepted, to complete the house within a reasonable time. The old house has some valuable material in it which could be used to advantage in the new building.

Mr. Strapp stated he could arrange accommodation for himself and his wife by taking over one of the small cottages now rented to a party working on the experimental farm. This arrangement would make it possible to salvage the lumber from the old house and rebuild on the present site. It is desirable to do this in order to use the present water line as well as the old septic tank. It is very expensive to build at the present time due to the high cost of material and the advance in wages, however, in this particular case we have certain advantages -

1. It may be possible to salvage from the old house enough dimension to put up the frame and build the partitions and in addition we should be able to obtain a large quantity of boards, which can be used for sheeting and roof purposes.

2. A new furnace was installed last winter in the old residence. This, of course, is in good condition and can be used for the new house.

3. Some two or three years ago we purchased shingles to repair a roof of a barn. The work was never done and now Mr. Strapp has recommended the barn be taken down. These shingles could be used for the new house.

4. I think Mr. Strapp would be willing to undertake digging the basement for the new house. All this extra should make it possible to complete the house within the allowance, namely, $10,000.00.

In connection with Mr. Hoey's memorandum of June 14, 1947, bearing your notations of the 17th instant, together with an attached copy of a telegram received from the Rev. O.B. Strapp, you are advised as follows:

Re: Principal's Residence,
Brandon Residential School

I have received your letter dated June 16th together with the plan for the proposed house. The situation is somewhat difficult to handle due -

1. To the fact that we have no specifications
2. The old house must be demolished as we wish to build on the same site
3. Materials from the old house should be salvaged for the new structure
4. We have in the old house a new oil furnace - same to be used for the new house
5. A quantity of new shingles is on hand - perhaps enough for the house

No doubt the Department would expect the work to be supervised by an engineer and in view of this I think it advisable to ask Mr. Gow of the Dominion Water & Power Bureau, Surveys and Engineering Branch, to take charge now and present to those called on to tender complete requirements and specifications both in relation to demolishing the old house and erecting the new house.

I have already approached the following contractors -

Higgins & Sons
Lissaman & Spratling
Mr. R. C. Shanks, Brandon

Mr. Walter Erickson, Brandon,
representing Pearson Bros.,
Winnipeg

The first two listed stated they could only take the work on a cost plus basis. Mr. Erickson when interviewed was prepared to quote on a cost plus basis or to give a quotation on a complete job. Mr. Shanks was not sure he could consider the work because -

a. He was already committed to quite a large programme of work
b. He only had a couple of helpers
c. He could not be sure of securing materials - He will, however, give the matter further consideration.

over
Will the Department please instruct regarding -

1. If and when specifications will be available

2. Does the Department approve of asking assistance from the Dominion Water & Power Bureau, Surveys and Engineering Branch?

I understand Mr. Gow is now doing work at the Branch School in connection with the high pressure boiler.

3. Should quotations be obtained from all listed above? Are there any additional contractors who should be consulted?

A prompt reply will be appreciated.

Yours truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.
Ottawa, July 4th, 1947.

Mr. A.G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies, Winnipeg, Manitoba.

We have your letter of June 24th with reference to the principal's residence at the Brandon Indian Residential School.

You have no doubt received the plan of the building that we propose to erect. This was obtained from the Department of Agriculture and they do not supply any specifications. This is due to present conditions when materials are so difficult to obtain and they have found it more satisfactory to allow their officers to decide what materials should be used, keeping in mind any materials that are locally available.

Reverend Mr. Strapp, principal of the Brandon School has had considerable experience in building and I suggest that Mr. Strapp and yourself confer immediately with the under mentioned firms:

Mr. Walter Erickson
Higgins & Sons
Lissaman & Spratling

It might be inferred from your letter that Mr. Erickson is most interested in erecting the building and if both of you interview him he will possibly be in a position to advise you regarding the materials that are obtainable and might assist you in preparing specifications.

If at all possible, you should obtain quotations from all three firms mentioned above.
and these quotations should include not only the erection of the new building but the demolishing of the old house on the understanding that some of the material should be salvaged for the new structure and that the oil furnace and shingles which are on hand can be used.

It should be kept in mind that the total amount available is $10,000. As soon as you have received the quotations you should submit same for our consideration.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I am taking the privilege of writing to you re the Indian Residential School at Brandon, Manitoba.

In June I was privileged to be the adjudicator for the Music Recital held in the school, as prizes were awarded for the performances. I was very interested and anxious to know what response would be made to musical instruction to these Indian children. I must say, I was tremendously impressed with the results. There were some twelve pupils in the class. These children have been taking piano instruction from Mrs. McNeill, a member of the Staff. She has been doing this entirely on a voluntary basis, providing music etc., for the sake of experiment.

I think Mrs. McNeill is to be commended for the work she has done, under limitations. The piano is in bad shape. It should at least be in tune, to cultivate tonal appreciation. And the periods for practice were very limited.

These pupils, with few exceptions, played a hymn with their selected pieces and I was amazed at their interpretation. What an asset to the missionary when they return to their homes. I have been wondering Mr. Hamilton and this has prompted me to write you, could it be arranged to have said instrument improved in condition or a better one put in its place? Also, could a place be given in the curriculum of the school's activities to give those children who show interest a chance to develop the art? Could their music be provided?

In time it might prove necessary to allot a teacher to this art alone.

The Junior and Intermediate pupils sang a group of two songs each. They were very good. In any school I feel this work means so much towards the development of character in students. I noticed two or three pupils with particular ability. On especially, if given a chance, I am satisfied he would go

-over
a long way in the field of music. These children had only had nine months tuition. I just wish some of my own pupils could have heard them.

Trusting that you will see fit to look into this subject and that Mrs. McNeill may be encouraged to continue with this valuable part of a child's education by those in charge of Indian Affairs,

I am yours sincerely,
Emma J. Muirhead, L.C.M.

WINNIPEG, August 29, 1947.

Re: Water Supply, Brandon Indian Residential School, Manitoba.

The writer recently visited Brandon in connection with the study to be made as to the practicability of connecting the Brandon Indian Residential School and the Dominion Experimental Farm of the Department of Agriculture with the City of Brandon water supply. The matter was discussed with the City Engineer of Brandon and the Superintendent of the Experimental Farm.

Superintendent Hopper of the Experimental Farm admitted that their water supply was somewhat precarious and that at present they had no measure whatsoever of fire protection. He appeared anxious that his department should co-operate with the Indian Affairs Branch in any arrangements that could be made for connecting up with the City of Brandon water supply. In fact, he had, a year ago, engaged in discussions with the Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School with reference to this matter. It was his idea that the study should be hurried so that water could be made available at the earliest possible date.

While we have secured certain plans which show the location of the Brandon pumping supply in relation to the Experimental Farm, these plans do not go beyond the Experimental Farm and so do not take in the lands of the Indian Residential School. We would request authorization from you to proceed to make certain surveys in connection with this project. These surveys would include the running of a line directly from the Brandon Pumping Station to the Experimental Farm and thence to the Indian Residential School. The survey would necessarily include more or less detailed work in connection with the buildings and the Indian Residential School inasmuch as we know of no plan at present existing for that Institution. This survey would cost in field expenses possibly $150.00 and I believe would be well worthwhile. I would, therefore, ask that you consider this matter and if it is deemed advisable to proceed to so advise us so that the work can be carried out during the month of September while we have the University Student Assistants available for the work. The survey party would only consist of two or three men for a period of possible one week.

An early reply would be greatly appreciated.

(Sgd.) D. B. Gow

Sept. 5, 1947.

Mr. W. J. Pratt,
Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Pratt:

An experienced builder of Brandon drove out with me last evening to the Residential School and we went all through the present residence. Coming back he gave me his candid impressions as to what he thinks is the only course to follow. The main house is fairly large with some lean-tos added later and then a massive verandah around three sides of the building.

There is no basement, just a hole dug in the ground. As a result the place is pretty badly out of plumb and beneath the surface which Mr. and Mrs. Strapp have managed to keep respectable looking, I believe the building is in bad shape.

Mr. Shanks who accompanied me, says that it is out of the question now to endeavor to secure cement and to get in the basement before hard frost sets in. It will be a rather slow undertaking to take down the present building and salvage most of the material. Salvaging is necessary as Mr. Shanks says the material is in good condition. The work would have to be done by some careful workmen or it would otherwise be largely destroyed. Then again the new building could not possibly be available this fall and the Strepps would have no place for the winter.
Mr. Shanks is of the opinion that it would be advisable to have everything in readiness to begin work about the first of May in view of conditions mentioned above and others. Then there are two or three slight changes that he and Mr. Strappe would recommend in the plan, these are only slight but would probably cost less and fit into the scheme better.

I am wondering whether you have in the Department an experienced builder who might be in the West and could stop over and inspect the whole project, if so I think it will be well to have Mr. Shanks along and they could on the ground decide the best course to follow.

Yours sincerely,

JEM/L.

Dear Sir;

Re; Destruction of Dairy Barn and Hog Barn by fire Friday Nov. 14, 1947.

At approximately 9.45 P.M. on the above noted date one of our senior boys, Solomon Hall, happened to glance out of the dormitory window and noticed a red glow at the end of the barn. Solomon called another boy, Walter Stonechild, and they then raised an alarm by knocking on the dormitory door.

Miss Cochrane investigated the noise and immediately called Mr. Osborne, the herdsman, and instructed the barn duty boys to get dressed and proceed to the barn.

I was then at the cottage, which I am using as a temporary residence, and was called by telephone. I at once notified the Brandon Fire Department and ask for their help.

I proceeded to the barn, taking with me two Pyrene extinguishers and a box of glass fire bombs. On arrival at the barn I made use of the extinguishers but owing to the strong wind which was blowing from the East I was unable to bring the flames, which were located under the eave of the building, under control.

I went inside the barn and inspected the milk room where a small sheet iron stove was in use to prevent the milking machine unit from freezing during the night. I found considerable smoke in the milk room but no sign of fire. The boys were now instructed to release the cattle and in a very short time had the 44 head, including a number of young calves, out of the barn and in an adjoining field.
The discipline of the boys was excellent, while of course somewhat excited by the fire, they responded at once to instructions and carried their duties out in a very creditable manner.

The detachment of the fire brigade arrived with their pumper unit but as we had not any water supply available they were not able to do more than attempt to give protection to the other buildings. In spite of their efforts it was not possible to save the hog barn which was in direct line of the fire and only about 25 feet due East of the dairy barn.

The Fire Marshal's representative has made an investigation, interviewing the two boys who first discovered the fire, Mr. Osborne our herdman, and myself.

I am of the opinion that the fire was caused by a spark from the chimney lodging under the eave of the building and being fanned into flame by the strong East wind.

I had personally made an inspection of the barns at about 8.00 P.M., and Mr. Osborne had visited the barn in the usual routine at about 8.30 P.M. The fire occurred just previous to the 10.00 P.M. inspection.

I have today made a survey of the concrete foundation and walls and am of the opinion that the present foundation could be used for the erection of a new barn but the walls would need a considerable amount of re-inforcing.

We have arranged temporary accommodation for the milking cows by turning the horses out in the bluff North of the main building and stabling the cows in the horse barn.

The old West barn is almost in a state of collapse and will require a considerable amount of shoring up before it will be safe to use as a shelter for the young cattle and hogs.

Yours truly,

Dear Ford:

Mr. Strapp phoned me tonight about their burned barn. Too bad, isn't it. I am not sure just what you can do about it. They have had to turn out their horses to make room for their milch cows in a poorly conditioned building at the best. Their young cattle, about 60 head altogether, are mostly also outside.

I think if you write him, Rev. O. B. Strapp, to assure him that everything possible will be done, etc., it will ease his mind considerably. Mr. Strapp is a good man and his concern over the situation is commended. He was in no way critical.

Shall see you soon.

J. E. Matthews.

Barn destroyed by fire at Brandon Residential School.

We have now received a complete report on the fire at the above Residential School, and it would seem to indicate that this was purely accidental and could not have been avoided. However, we have not yet received a report on the investigation made by the representative of the Fire Marshall.

Dr. Dorey, of the United Church of Canada, visited this office on Friday last, and we discussed the matter of replacing the barn early in the spring of 1948. In view of your close knowledge of the situation at Brandon, your recommendation would be appreciated as to the following proposals, which are made as a result of my meeting with Dr. Dorey:

(a) That Reverend Mr. Strapp be requested to prepare a plan for the proposed new barn;

(b) That this plan be submitted to the Department for approval;

(c) That a bill of materials be then prepared for the items required for this barn;

(d) That these materials be purchased through our Departmental Purchasing Agent;

(e) That the barn be then constructed early in the spring of 1948 on a day labour, contract or fixed fee basis.

It is possible that Mr. Higgins might be interested...
in the construction of this building, in view of the fact that he is at present building a new Principal's residence for the Reverend Mr. Strapp.

I am sending an extra copy of this letter to you, in the event that you would wish to forward it to the Reverend Mr. Strapp.

Enc.

The undersigned has the honour to report—

That under Vote 161 of the 1947-1948 estimates of the Department of Mines and Resources, funds have been provided for revisions to the Domestic Hot Water Services, and Boiler Equipment at the Brandon Indian Residential School, Brandon, Manitoba;

That lump sum tenders based on drawings and specifications prepared by the Department, were invited through the medium of the Departmental District Engineer in Winnipeg, Manitoba;

That bona-fide tenders, in accordance with Instructions to Tenderers were received from firms and in amounts as follows:—

| Name of Contractor | Total Amount |
|--------------------|--------------|
| Neale Stothard and Chapman, Brandon, Manitoba | $12,758.86 |
| Randall and Company Limited, 805 Portage Avenue, Winnipeg, Manitoba | $4,657.00 |

That tenders not in accordance with instructions to tenderers were received from firms, and who submitted proposals as follows:—

Rolf Plumbing and Heating, 126 Ninth Street, Brandon, Manitoba ———— cost plus 10 per cent.

John Planton Company Limited, 244 Main Street, Winnipeg, Manitoba ———— cost plus 10 per cent.

That the lowest lump sum tender was analysed, found to be in accordance with the drawings and specifications prepared by the Department, was accompanied by the required security deposit, and is considered fair and just;

That the need for the hereinmentioned revisions is urgent, and that the work should be undertaken at as early a date as possible.

The undersigned therefore, has the honour to recommend that he be authorized to accept the lowest lump sum tender submitted by the said firm of Neale, Stothard and Chapman of Brandon, Manitoba, and enter into a contract with them for the execution of the work in accordance with the drawings, and specifications prepared by the Department, and the said firm's lump sum tender price of Twelve Thousand Seven Hundred and Ninety-three Dollars and Ninety-six Cents ($12,758.86) entailing with provision for contingencies and supervision an approximate total expenditure of Fourteen Thousand Dollars ($14,000.00) such total expenditure to be met from the appropriate funds of the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The work shall, in every particular, be under and subject to the control and supervision of the Indian Agent.

(d) If and when the Minister shall so direct, the Contractor shall make no payment by way of royalties or otherwise with respect to any patent rights referred to in any statement furnished by the Contractor as provided in sub-section (c) of this section, except with the consent of the Minister and subject to such conditions as the Minister may impose and from and after the giving of any such direction by the Minister, His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against any action, claim or proceeding for infringement of the patent rights covered by such direction or for non-payment of royalties or other payments in respect thereof.

22. SANITATION

The Contractor shall comply with, and the work shall be carried on subject to all regulations made by any lawful authority and applicable to said work, and all orders given by the Indian Agent with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the work. The Contractor shall make adequate arrangements, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for the medical and sanitary supervision of all his employees.

23. INDIAN AGENT'S MARKS

The Contractor shall protect, and shall not remove or destroy, or permit to be removed or destroyed, the stakes, buoys and other marks placed on or about the said work by the Indian Agent or his assistants, and shall furnish the necessary assistance to correct or replace any stake, buoy or mark which through any cause may have been removed or destroyed.

24. NOTICES

Any notice, order, direction or other communication given to the Contractor under any of the provisions of this contract shall be sufficiently given if delivered to the Contractor personally, or to his foreman, or left at the Contractor's office, or mailed at any post office to the Contractor or foreman addressed to the address mentioned in the contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business or residence.

25. PROGRESS MEASUREMENTS AND CERTIFICATES NOT BINDING

The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as binding upon the Indian Agent or as final measurements or as fixing final amounts; they are to be subject to the revision of the Indian Agent in making up his final certificate, and they shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work or as a release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof.
26. PROTECTION OF WORK

The Contract and all information issued in connection therewith are confidential and their use must be strictly confined to the work and to the purpose of the contract; and particulars contained therein, and other matter issued in connection therewith, must not be disclosed to unauthorized persons.

The Contractor shall at all times take and cause to be taken all reasonable measures, for the protection of the work against espionage and sabotage, and on the order of the Minister shall dispense with the services of any person employed in, about or upon the work or cause the same to be dispensed with. The Minister shall at all times through such agency as he may see fit be entitled to maintain on or about the premises where the work or any part thereof is being carried on such police or other protective force as in the opinion of the Minister may be advisable.

27. CANADIAN WORK AND MATERIALS

To the full extent that the same are procurable, only Canadian labour, parts and materials (unless otherwise agreed by the Minister) shall be used in connection with the work.

27a. EMPLOYMENT OF EX-SERVICE MEN

In engaging labour for the work contemplated by this contract, either from the National Employment Service or from Trade Unions with which the contractor has collective agreements, the contractor shall specify that preference shall be given to competent and available ex-service men.

The contractor shall maintain and keep available for inspection by the Minister a record of the names and addresses of ex-service men employed, together with a record of the steps taken to implement this requirement.

28. SALARIES

The salaries payable to engineers, superintendents, draftsmen and foremen shall only be such as shall be approved by the Minister.

29. TERMINATION

(a) Notwithstanding anything in this contract contained the Minister may, by giving notice to the Contractor, terminate the contract (save and except the provisions of this section and of Section 19 of these general conditions) as regards all or any part or parts of the work or works not theretofore completed. Upon such notice being given, the Contractor shall cease work (including the procuring of materials for the fulfilment of the contract) in accordance with and to the extent specified in such notice but shall proceed with all reasonable speed to complete such part or parts (if any), to be worked on as are by the terms of such notice to be completed and shall also proceed with all reasonable speed to complete up to such time and/or stage as may be specified in the notice any part or parts of the work or works as required by such notice. The Minister may, at any time, or from time to time give one or more additional notices with respect to any or all parts of the work which remain to be completed after the giving of any previous notice or notices.

(b) All work completed by the Contractor under or pursuant to the provisions of the contract before or after the giving of any notice, subject to acceptance by His Majesty in accordance with the provisions of the contract, shall be paid for on the basis provided in the agreement (the Contractor being allowed such fraction of his
stipulated fee as shall be proportionate to the amount of the work (therefore completed), and the Contractor shall be entitled to be reimbursed the actual cost to the contractor of work not completed under or pursuant to the provisions of this contract and/or any notice given pursuant thereto plus a fair and reasonable profit in respect of work done thereon, provided that no reimbursement shall be made for materials which have been or may be rejected after inspection as not complying with the terms and conditions of this contract and the specifications.

(c) In the event that the Contractor and the Minister are unable to agree upon the amount in respect of which the Contractor is entitled to be reimbursed as aforesaid, the matter shall be referred to the Exchequer Court.

(d) Whenever practicable the Contractor shall procure materials required for the performance of the contract on terms that will enable it to terminate any contracts entered into by the Contractor upon conditions and terms similar in effect to those herein provided for in respect to termination by the Minister and the delivery of materials or work as aforesaid, and generally the Contractor shall cooperate with His Majesty and the Minister and do everything reasonably within its power at all times to minimize and reduce the amount of His Majesty's obligations under the provisions of this section.

(e) Upon reimbursement being made to the Contractor as herein provided, title to the materials and/or work in progress in respect of which such reimbursement is made shall pass to and vest in His Majesty (the Contractor hereby agreeing to execute and deliver all requisite instruments by way of further assurance) and the materials and/or work in progress shall be delivered to the order of the Minister, but the materials thus taken over will in no case be in excess of what would have been required for performing the contract in full if no notice had been given under the provisions hereof.

(f) If it is established to the satisfaction of the Minister by the Contractor that by reason of any action taken by the Minister under the provisions of this section exceptional hardship has resulted to the Contractor then the Minister may, notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, in his absolute discretion grant such allowance (not to include, in any case, however, any allowance or compensation for loss of profit) to the Contractor as, in the opinion of the Minister is warranted by the circumstances.

(g) Any action, decision or determination by the Minister under the provisions of this section shall be final and binding upon the Contractor.

(h) The Contractor shall have no claim for damages, compensation loss of profit, allowance or otherwise by reason of or directly or indirectly arising out of any action taken or notice given by the Minister under or pursuant to the provisions of this section except as and to the extent in this section expressly provided.

(i) The right of termination and of giving notice hereinbefore provided shall be in addition to and not in substitution for any other right possessed by His Majesty and/or the Minister.

30. LABOUR CONDITIONS

The Contractor shall comply with and be subject to all the terms and conditions of the Labour Conditions (if any) referred to in the agreement and to all variations and modifications thereof that may at any time be enacted or brought into force during the continuance of the contract.

(b) Payments shall be made only on the production and delivery by the Contractor to the Minister of a certificate in writing signed by the Indian Agent and, if required by the Minister, by a cost accountant appointed or approved by the Minister, certifying the amount to which the contractor is entitled as aforesaid;

(c) The Contractor shall, when making his final requisition for payment furnish to the Indian Agent satisfactory evidence supported by a statutory declaration in form approved by the Minister establishing payment by the Contractor of the items listed in all preceding requisitions and such other information as the Minister may require;

(e) Five copies of all progress claims and summaries of invoices in connection with the work shall be rendered by the Contractor to the Indian Agent.

Time shall be deemed to be material and of the essence of this contract.

The Minister may, through the Indian Agent from time to time, by written instruction or drawings issued to the Contractor, make changes in the work, issue additional instructions, require additional work or direct the omission of work previously ordered, and the provisions of the contract shall apply to all such changes, modifications and additions with the same effect as if they were embodied in the contract plans, drawings and specifications.

7. WORK SUBJECT TO CONTROL OF INDIAN AGENT.

The work shall, in every particular, be under and subject to the control and supervision of the Indian Agent.

8. FOREMAN OF WORKERS.

A competent foreman shall be kept on the ground by the Contractor during working hours, to receive the orders of the Indian Agent. Such foreman shall be considered as the lawful representative of the Contractor and shall carry out all requisitions and instructions of the Indian Agent.

9. DEFECTIVE WORK OR MATERIAL.

10. CONSUMABLE TOOLS, MATERIALS AND SUPPLIES.

All usable tools (other than tools customarily provided by tradesmen) and all consumable materials and supplies left over after the completion of the work shall, if the Minister so desires, be taken over and be paid for by the Contractor at a fair and reasonable price to be determined by the Minister.

11. WORK NOT COMPRISED IN CONTRACT.
