PLANNING THE BARN

Experimental Farms Service,
Central Experimental Farm,
Ottawa, Canada,
F.W. Graves, Architect.

Before building a new barn or remodeling an old one, a careful study of barn plans should be undertaken. Visit and study existing barns in the neighborhood. Faults and mistakes may be seen in the old and avoided in the new. Good ideas may be noted and used to advantage. The farm barn is a heavy investment and troubles resulting from bad planning are very serious and lasting. In a well built and well planned barn there will be a reduction of time and labour in caring for the stock, a decrease in the loss of young animals and an increase in milk production. The animals sheltered in the barn should return a fair income on the cost of the building. High producing cows will justify a reasonably greater expenditure for shelter.

Some of the more important factors to be considered in planning the barn are location, convenience of planning, type of construction, window area, cubic air space, ventilation and equipment.

LOCATION - The site should be dry and well drained. Such a site will avoid much excessive dampness in the barn and feed rooms and mud in the barnyard. The barn should be located where prevailing winds will not blow from the barn towards the house, carrying odours from the stable and yard. It is preferable, if otherwise convenient, to run the building north and south so that the sides will get the morning and afternoon sun, which is an advantage in regulating stable temperatures. In planning the layout of the farm buildings, much can be done to reduce the fire risk. Where buildings are closely grouped, considerable time and labour is saved in doing chores and carrying out the routine of farm work. This gain, however, will hardly offset the risk of heavy loss from fire. In this respect it is better economy to have the buildings well separated. It is recommended that there should be a clear space of at least 150 feet between the principal farm buildings. Fire risk can be reduced also by so locating these buildings that the prevailing winds will blow across the line of the buildings.

TYPE - In general purpose barns, cattle and horses are frequently kept together, but good practice calls for dairy herds to be separated at least by tight partitions from horses. There are many types of construction and shapes and styles of barn. The earlier barns in this country were built with heavy timber frames, mortised and tenoned, braced and pinned. These barns were usually roofed with a single pitch from ridge to eaves. Later the gambrel roof with two and sometimes even three slopes became popular. So-called "Gothic" or "round" roofed barns have also been built in many parts of the country. Great variations in plan and arrangement occur, with level cross drive barn floors, bank barns with the variant of cross drive and longitudinal drive floors, rectangular, L, U, or T-shaped plans, octagonal plans, and circular plans. In recent years mowless one storey cow barns with separate hay or ensilage storage have been looked upon with favour by some farmers. The latter type must have roof as well as walls insulated.

In construction, plank frame, braced rafter or laminated rafter construction have superseded almost entirely the old timber frame on account of their greater economy in the use of materials and labour. The gambrel roof seems to be the simplest and most practical shape. The "Gothic" type has the advantage of somewhat greater clear space in the loft, but there have been a number of failures in this type and great care must be taken in the construction of the rafters or ribs.

STALL ARRANGEMENT - The question of facing in or facing out is one for the individual farmer to decide as both have their advantages. With stock facing out, cleaning may be done from one alley, which is often arranged as a wide central drive; most of the work is done behind the stock; the mangers receive sunlight; the stock displays better and it is easier to bring the animals in one door. Advantages for stock facing in are more convenient in feeding which is done from one alley (this is a more frequent operation than milking or cleaning), the gutters get more sunlight which helps sanitation, better light for milking, two doors avoid crowding at the entrance and the ventilation system is more easily installed.

COW STALLS - These vary from 3' -0" to 4' -0" in width with an average of 3' -4" or 3' -6" and from 4' -3" to 5' -6" in length. It is possible to accommodate both large and small animals by varying the length of the platform from one end of the row to the other end, with adjustable steel stanchions, almost any desired length may be
secured. Gutters vary from 16" to 18" in width, with a depth of 4" to 6" on the alley side and 7" to 9" on the stall side. High and low manger fronts each have certain advantages.

CONSTRUCTION - Concrete is about the only really satisfactory dairy stable floor, being durable and easily kept clean; in horse stalls, plank overlays, brick or creosoted wood paving blocks may be used. Plank floors should be removable for cleaning. Always use plenty of good bedding. Mangers and gutters should have a fall of 1" in 25' -0" up to a length of 50' -0". In longer barns, they should pitch from the ends towards the centre. They should have drains with plugs so that they may be properly flushed.

Walls may be of stone, tile, concrete or frame. An air space should be provided in masonry walls. The concrete wall may be carried up one foot only, up to the window sills or up to the loft floor, with frame above. Where the wood frame starts one foot above the floor, a warm, well insulated wall can be provided without great expense. For framing the gambrel roof either the braced rafter or the plank frame may be used. In the braced rafter, which is suitable for widths up to 36' -0", where the loft side walls are not more than 10' -0", each upper rafter is braced to each lower rafter and each lower rafter to the wall studding. The plank frame consists of trusses spaced at 10' -0" to 14' -0" on centres, with purlins running the length of the barn. The quantity of lumber in the two types is approximately the same. The braced rafter does not require any pieces over 14' -0" in length, in the 34' width or over 16' -0" in the 36' width. It is therefore sometimes more economical and is almost equally as strong.

LIGHT - Ample window space should be provided. Regulations vary a great deal in this respect, but the average requirement is 4 square feet of glass per cow. Windows should be higher than their width as more floor area receives sunlight in this way. A suitable window consists of two sashes (each 6 light 10" x 12") the lower being fixed and the upper hinged to the lower to drop inwards on checks or a chain; a twelve light window of the type provides 10 square feet of glass. For box stalls, a six light sash is usually satisfactory and light may be provided for these on a basis of 1 sq. ft. of glass to 20 or 25 sq. ft. of floor area. Storm sash will add considerably to the comfort of the barn in winter.

VENTILATION - Animals in a poorly ventilated barn require more feed to maintain body weight and condition and to keep up production than those in proper surroundings. Without proper circulation, the air, warmed by the animals rises and condenses on windows, walls and ceilings causing a damp barn. From 500 to 700 cu. ft. of air should be allowed per cow, which means that the ceiling shall be about 5' -0", and the floor 8' -0" high. If the barn is well lighted, the number of square inches of glass per sq. ft. of floor area is less, the ceilings may be reduced in height. In the average Canadian climate, insulation of the walls as well as the ceiling of the stable is advisable. The hay in the loft of the ordinary farm barn provides perfect insulation of the ceiling. In a one storey barn, some other form of insulation must be installed to take its place.

Inlets should be well distributed over the building. Each one should not be more than 50 to 100 square inches in area. They should always be provided with control dampers. The outlet must be tightly built, say of two ply matched lumber with paper between, and must also be equipped with a damper. These may vary in size; 20" to 26" square is usual in the Rutherford system, and often much larger in the single out-take modified King system. A table is given on the drawing indicating approximate flue sizes required.

EQUIPMENT - High costs of farm labour may sometimes warrant the installation of equipment that will save additional help and thus reduce expense. All equipment such as litter and feed carriers, milking machines, etc., should be carefully planned before the barn is built in order to avoid unnecessary cutting and fitting to install this equipment later.

RULES AND REGULATIONS - In most provinces of Canada there are Health By-laws governing certain requirements for Stable buildings. Inquiries should be made direct to the Board of Health or other local authority as to the regulations in force in the particular province, or in the milk district to which milk may be shipped. These regulations cover such matters as distances from barn to piggery, to manure shed, to milk house; window area for light, cubic content of stable or air space per cow, ventilation, etc.

We are in receipt of a letter from Mr. D.B. Gow, dated February 2, 1946, in connection with the vertical high pressure boiler which was rented last July for temporary use at the above.

Reviewing the circumstances which made this action necessary, you are advised that Principal O.B. Strapp of Brandon, Manitoba, wired the Indian Affairs Branch on June 14th to the effect that the existing vertical high pressure boiler used for laundry services had collapsed and was beyond repair. This was not unexpected as our Mr. Hargreaves, following an inspection of the boiler room equipment in June 1946, reported in a memorandum to Mr. Wardle dated June 20, 1946, that this Division would take no responsibility for the continued operation of the unit under the existing circumstances.

A memorandum dated June 14th was received from the Indian Affairs Branch, requesting this Division to take immediate action with regard to renting a high pressure boiler for use in the school until the plant revisions were carried out.

On the same date a telegram was despatched to Mr. D.B. Gow, requesting him to rent a vertical high pressure boiler for an estimated several months duration. It should be brought to your attention that this unit will not be needed when the plant revisions are completed as the new work includes for a different type of high pressure boiler, one having capacity to serve not only the laundry but also the large domestic hot water demand.

After some difficulty, Mr. Gow located and rented a 10 horsepower vertical high pressure boiler, at a rental charge of $25.00 per month plus carriage from Winnipeg to Brandon in the amount of $15.00. These accounts he was asked to certify and pass on to the Indian Affairs Branch for payment.

Due to circumstances beyond our control, the revisions to the boiler room equipment have been delayed beyond our expectation, extending the continued use of the rented boiler; and to date no rental invoices have been received by this Division.

Mr. Gow suggests in his letter referred to above, that the Department give consideration to purchasing this boiler outright for possible future use elsewhere. In this aim, he contacted the owners J. Hayes and Sons, of Winnipeg, and they have agreed to abandon the rental account and to sell the boiler to the Department for a price of $225.00 plus interest at the rate of 6% calculated from July 1st to the date of payment. This total charge will amount to approximately $235.00.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
It can be assumed that this boiler will be needed at Brandon, Manitoba, for another three months, which added to the seven months already passed since this installation will make a total rental charge of $250.00. Should the boiler be returned to its owners an additional dismantling and cartage charge will be incurred which would amount to approximately $50.00. Added to the rental charges for approximately ten months, the total would be $300.00.

It is felt advisable under the circumstances to recommend to Indian Affairs Branch the purchase of this unit, which is reported to be in good condition, for possible use elsewhere at a later date. It is felt likely that storage space could be found either at the Brandon or Portage la Prairie Indian Residential Schools.

Since Mr. Gow has asked for an early decision in connection with this purchase, we would appreciate receiving your instructions so that he may be advised as to what action he should take.

Chief Engineer.

Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

It was our intention to include in the final 1947-48 Supplementary Estimates a sum to cover the expenditures required by the awarding of a contract for repairs at this school to Messrs. Neale, Stothart and Chapman.

Dear Sir;

Following receipt of a copy of your letter
123-0-5 (WT) December 2, 1947, through Mr. Hamilton's office,
I have prepared a plan for the new Dairy Barn to be erected
to replace that destroyed by fire last November.

Various plans and designs were considered. Visits were paid to
a number of large dairy barns in the vicinity of Brandon and
Winnipeg. A study was made of barn dimensions, placement of
doors, windows, stalls, feed alleys, etc., and special attention was
paid to ventilating systems.

A rough draft plan was made and, upon the advice of Mr. R.M. Hopper,
Supt. of the Experimental Farm, Brandon, was submitted to the
Architect, Dominion Experimental Farms, Ottawa, for suggestions
and criticism.

Suggestions made by Mr. Graves, Ottawa, were incorporated, as
also was the ventilating system recommended by Prof. Shanks of
the Department of Agriculture, University of Manitoba.

The idea of constructing an all metal barn similar to those
at Muncey, Ontario, could not be entertained owing to the fact
that steel is in such short supply. I am assured that lumber
will be available.

I contacted Beatty Bros. Ltd., and they have assured me that
stanchions, pen fittings, water bowls, etc., will be made available
on order for early Spring.
Several contractors in Brandon would be willing to submit a bid for the erection of the barn. Mr. E.C. Higgen's, who is at present engaged in the erection of the new residence would be willing to undertake the work upon terms similar to his present contract.

If I can be of further service in this matter I shall be only too willing to co-operate with your Branch.

I remain,

Yours truly,

Re: Water Supply - Brandon Indian Residential School, Manitoba.

Referring to a memorandum from Indian Affairs, dated April 9, 1947, we have now received a report from Mr. W.H. Wallace, dated March 11, 1948, with covering letter from Mr. Gow, dated March 18, 1948. Triplicate copies of the report, with plans and covering letter, are attached herewith.

From the figures given in the report it can be inferred that the capacity of the present Brandon pumping plant is in excess of present consumption, but we do not yet know whether the filtration plant has the same excess capacity. However, one would not anticipate that the city would object to supplying the small amount of domestic water needed for the Brandon Residential School and for the Experimental Farm on the basis of lack of capacity of the plant. Fire requirements might be a different matter.

You will note that the cost of the proposal to supply both institutions (School and Farm) from one system connected to the Brandon supply is estimated at approximately $50,000.00. This figure might not cover the cost of distribution lines to individual buildings and the cost of securing right of way.

Mr. Gow intends to explore the possibilities of securing water for the School from a deep well and this general information is necessary and will be useful in coming to a final decision.

Securing water from the City of Brandon has many advantages, and if the cost can be shared with the Experimental Farm Service the scheme might be attractive to both the Indian Affairs Branch and the Experimental Farm Service of the Department of Agriculture.

The cost might be reduced by the elimination of fire protection and the use of smaller pipe which would save money on materials, but other installation costs would not be reduced to any great extent. Owing to the high elevation of the School a step would be needed to give efficient fire service after the pipes have deteriorated in capacity some years after installation. The figures on fire pressures in the report seem to be a trifle optimistic and based on the capacity of fairly new pipes.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,

Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I have your letter of the above noted date and file number.

I note that memorandum differentiates between 'Fire protection' and 'Domestic supply'.

Re Fire Protection; Throughout this section of the country large 'Dug Outs' have been excavated during the last few years and these maintain a reasonably high level of water. An excavation approximately 40' X 20' X 15' in depth would hold an average of 30,000 to 40,000 gallons of water even during dry seasons. One of these dug outs located reasonable close to the barns would provide sufficient water for the Brandon City pumper in the event of a fire occurring. A small pumping unit housed near the barns could be used by the staff of the school until the arrival of the large unit. The whole installation would not be very costly and the upkeep would be light.

Re Domestic Supply; I am still of the opinion that if the present 'High' and 'Low' springs were properly exploited it would be possible to obtain a sufficient supply for our domestic use. The wooden dam constructed just below the 'High' spring has opened in a number of places and should be replaced with interlocking steel plates driven into the ground. The wooden box which is located at the spring should be replaced with a concrete tank with weeping tile running into it. The present storage tank...
should be augmented by the addition of another tank of similar dimensions.

If the above noted suggestions were carried out, a large quantity of water that is now being lost would be conserved.

Another item to be kept in mind is the additional grant which would be required to pay for the water which it is proposed to buy from the City of Brandon. I believe that the Residential school at Portage La Prairie is paying approximately $60.00 a month for their domestic supply from the city. This school would probably be taxed $100.00 per month and that amount could not be paid out of the per capita grant at the present rate.

I expect to be in Ottawa on Friday of this week and will be glad to discuss the matter further with you then.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Principal.

Brandon Indian Residential School - Mr. Strapp, the Principal, appears to be running a very good school. His buildings and grounds were in fair condition. However, his attitude is that the Department should do all the repairs, and very little repair is done by any of the school staff.

The basement and ground floor are badly in need of re-decorating. In the boy's playroom the wainscoting is in very bad shape, and urgently in need of repairs. It is all broken and in terrible condition. I would recommend that this be repaired before the school opens, also some decorating be done on the floors mentioned.

The contractor is busy putting in the new boiler, and this work should be completed before the school opens. I would strongly recommend that the school be forced to hire an engineer with at least 3rd class papers to look after the heating equipment after it has been repaired, and a new boiler put in. In the past they have had a low pressure boiler and the new one is high pressure. Without proper care it will not last as long as it should.

The cattle barn, which burned last fall, should be replaced before the school opens, as the cattle barn where they are keeping the cows at present is very unsuitable for this purpose, and very unsanitary. I cannot find anything on file regarding this fire or barn, and request that you give me any information you have on hand. Also, if it is the intention of the Department to replace it this year.

This school, like most Protestant schools, has locked doors, and takes on the appearance more of a jail than a school. If the Department insisted that this practice was discontinued, I think we would find that the children would take better care of the Department property and buildings. At present they feel that they are not trusted, and it makes them more or less hostile and they do not appreciate what is being done for them.

Memorandum

Mr. D. B. Gow

Re:- Brandon Indian Residential School,
Domestic Water Supply

The domestic water supply from the "high spring" was examined on the occasion of a visit to the school on October 8 last.

A pipe line, as shown on a plan of work performed in 1941, connects the wooden well structure at the main spring and the double concrete cistern at the dam. The water level in the upper well is 9.3 feet above the inlet to the concrete cistern 180' away, yet the yield to the cistern was estimated at one gallon per minute on the date of the visit. It is believed that this pipe line should be repaired and put back in operation as soon as possible to assist in maintaining all available yield from the spring for the coming winter. There is a possibility that a critically low water supply may be experienced due to dry conditions and lack of precipitation this fall.

The wooden well at the main spring, although very small, appears to be in a fair state of repair. The sheet piling cutoff near the cistern is broken at ground level in places and while not effective in retaining surface water, it is believed that it retards subsurface flow.

The outline of work proposed is briefly as follows:

Excavate to the level of the present 4" field tile line, beginning at the lower end.

Relay the 4" tile on prepared continuous cradles of 2" material as excavating progresses.

Backfill with 6" of gravel, then earth as the tile are laid.

It is felt that the excavation costs will be relatively high on this undertaking due to the possible necessity for pumping and for shoring of the trench. However, should there be any unspent funds, it is felt that they should be used to increase the flow into the wooden well at the main spring by the laying of a field drain underneath the present ditch leading to the well.

Following is an estimate of the probable cost of repairing the feed line from the sump to the concrete cistern:

Memorandum

Mr. D. B. Gow

Re: Water Supply, Brandon Indian Residential School, Manitoba.

During the period November 24 to December 3, 1948, the tile line connecting the "Upper Spring" to the concrete tank was relaid. The original line was of 4" clay tile, with a 4" cast iron pipe 25' in length connecting the tile to the tank. Alignment of the tile was found to be good except near the spring where the soil is very unstable. The tile line for a short distance near Station 0+50 was partially blocked with a fine fibrous growth which existed wholly within the tile.

The accompanying sketch represents the relaid tile line. Work was started at the lower end of the line in order to keep the trench as much as possible free from water. Soil for the greater distance of the line was found to be compact and stable making it unnecessary to provide any additional support to maintain alignment of the tile. The clay tile were inspected for breaks and possible obstructions before being relaid. Tar paper strips were used to cover the tile joints and the trench was filled with gravel to a depth of 1½ feet above the tile. Earth was placed to complete the backfill. At Station 0+56 due to water a 4" wye was introduced to the line and a secondary line run in advance to keep the trench dry. Quicksand was encountered at Station 0+36 making the use of field tile impracticable. Vitrified sewer tile were laid from this point to the spring. A metal mesh covering was here placed around the pipe inlet to prevent any obstruction from entering the line.

Approximately $240.00 was spent on the outlined repairs. This amount includes labour, materials used, and the writer's living expenses while engaged on this work.

Dear Sir:

We have been able to adapt a Quonset All-Steel building to your plans for a proposed barn at the Indian School, Brandon, and take pleasure in presenting this proposal for your approval.

The barn will consist of a Quonset All-Steel building 36x100 interior measurements. The foundation will consist of a slab-type pad with the necessary concrete mangers for the Beatty Brothers Equipment, formed into the floor.

The walls of the building, to the underside of the loft floor, will be insulated with 2" rock wool batts and the necessary vapour seal paper. The wall of the main floor section of the barn, including the ceiling, will be lined with asbestos "Flexboard."

The milk room will consist of one section of a Quonset 2C attached to the main structure, and will measure 20x12 inside. This room to be lined and insulated as above.

The loft floor will be of 2" poured concrete on steel sheets, nailed to Stran Steel joists placed on 16" centres. The loft to be supported by steel pipe columns on 20' centres throughout the building. These columns will not interfere with Beatty Brothers Equipment specified for the main floor. The loft will contain 40,000 cu. ft. and will have 3,300 sq. ft. of floor space.

There will be four 20" roof ventilators to ventilate the insulated walls and one 20" roof vent, with necessary duct, to remove foul air from the main section of the barn.
Doors and windows will be of standard Quonset make and will be situated as close as possible to your original plan. The doors will consist of 3'6"x7' steel walk doors where specified and a 12x9 steel sliding door in the loft.

The whole of the above will cost .................. $31,787.00. This price subject to 30 days acceptance. Work to commence as soon as the frost is out of the ground in the Spring.

It is to be realized that a barn of this type would be 100% fire-proof, would be warm in the winter and cool in the summer, and would last for years with little or no maintenance.

May 18th, 1949.

Rev. O.B. Strapp,
Principal,
Brandon Residential School,
Brandon, Manitoba.

Dear Mr. Strapp:

We have just received another progress payment in connection with the construction of the Principal's residence at the Brandon Residential School. This payment brings the cost considerably higher than was originally intended. Of course, we realize that some of the extra cost was due to repairs to the foundation and other repairs necessary on account of the settlement of the original foundation.

However, it has been brought to our attention that acting on your authority, the new residence has been completely papered and an extra bathroom with fixtures has been installed. Departmental officials have been anxious to provide a suitable residence for you, but we feel that we have not received full cooperation when you authorize expenditures over and above what was called for in the plans and specifications, without first obtaining our approval.

Please let me hear from you at the earliest possible date, and at the same time, you should advise if the building has been completed, and if not, the approximate cost that will be required to finish it.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
PP/ST
Supt. of Indian Education
Ottawa, May 19th, 1949.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS & DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

Re: Brandon Indian Residential School No. 576

In a letter dated March 24th, 1949, Regional Supervisor Davis wrote us in part as follows:

"While at Brandon last week I was over the Indian Residential School and would like to draw certain matters to your attention.

The building, with the exception of the staff quarters, is in a very deplorable state of repair. The basement walls are badly in need of repairs and some rooms, such as the boys' playroom, are in very poor condition. The wainscoting is broken and the washroom is badly in need of repair. We should do something about redecorating the school this summer.

The playrooms have no facilities for the children to play games and only one or two benches to sit on. All the dormitories need redecorating. There are signs of the roof leaking in the sewing room and the boys' side of the building."

In replying to that letter we requested Mr. Davis to forward further information, and I enclose a copy of his letter together with a quotation he received from Pearson Construction Co. Ltd., Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dear Sir;

I have your letter of the above noted date and file number.

I regret very much that you have been given the impression that I have not been giving the fullest cooperation in the matter of the construction of the new house. It most certainly was not my intention to offend in any way.

May I say in explanation re the matter of the toilet and hand wash basin that was installed in the upper floor room, that I discussed with the plumber the substitution of these items in place of the laundry equipment that the plans called for in the basement as I found that in so many homes where laundry tubs etc were installed in the basement they were not used because of the heavy work entailed in carrying the wet clothing upstairs to hang it out of doors to dry. I did not expect that the amount of the finished contract would exceed the amount of the estimate. The finished job was billed at $1,405.58 the original estimated cost was $1,226.30, making a difference of $179.28. As the amount is not high I will be quite prepared to accept responsibility for the excess over the original estimate, if you consider I should do so.

With reference to the papering of the lower floor rooms, and the hall; When the house was jacked up to bring the floors to a level the plaster was badly cracked and in some places so uneven
that it was impossible to patch without stripping large surfaces, so that the patch would not show. In discussing this with the contractor it was decided that to paper the downstairs rooms and tint the walls of the rooms upstairs would be the best way to finish the job. This is what was done. It is to be regretted that your informant stated that the house had been "completely papered" as I most certainly would not have proceeded with such an expenditure without first consulting you as I did with reference to the refrigerator and the electric stove.

I have been unable to contact the contractor Mr. E.C. Higgins as he is out of town for a few days but have contacted the Painter who has submitted a provisional estimate for completing the work on the outside of the house at approximately $500.00. In accordance with your letter of June 10, 1949 I have made an inspection of this school and beg to report that the work now required may be referred to almost entirely as maintenance, which has apparently been deferred for at least several years. The school building generally is in the worst condition of any that I have visited to date and it is impossible to furnish you with definite cost estimates covering the many items that now require attention.

The major, but by no means the most important, matter that should now be attended to is the interior decorating of the school. Practically the whole interior of the school is badly in need of decorating and this is a matter that, according to the Rev. O. B. Stropp, Principal, has been under consideration for some time. Apparently several estimates regarding interior decorating have been obtained and submitted to Indian Affairs and I am forwarding herewith a copy of the latest which was obtained from Crane Bros., Brandon. This estimate, in the amount of $2,662.35, covers only those rooms that are most urgently in need of painting and this work, at least, should be done this year. The work could be done by Crane Bros. on the basis of the estimate submitted, or estimates could be obtained from other Brandon Contractors who might be asked to tender on the items covered by the Crane quotation.

The following additional items also require immediate attention at this school:

(1) The classrooms, although not included in the Crane estimate, are in need of attention. The plaster is badly cracked in places and should be repaired. Three 4' X 5' pieces of Ten-Test should be supplied for attachment to walls for use as notice boards in order to eliminate future damage to the walls.

(2) The walls of the boys' and girls' playrooms were lined with "V. Joint" between the floor and the lower level of the windows. This "V Joint" has been broken out and the plaster beneath gouged out at every break. New "V Joint" could be installed but
the same thing would no doubt happen to it in a short time. It is therefore recommended that the walls in these rooms be faced with cement from floor to window level. This work will have to be done before the painting of these rooms could be finished.

(3) The drinking fountain in the girls' playroom is in such bad shape that it can no longer be used and has been disconnected. A new fountain should be installed.

(4) The taps for the wash basins in both the boys' and girls' washrooms are all in bad shape and all need replacing. The taps on the bath tubs are in a similar condition. New taps should be supplied, 50 for the wash basins and 6 for bath tubs.

(5) The toilets in the boys' and girls' lavatories are likewise in bad condition. The old type of toilet installed here is anything but sanitary and I would suggest that new toilets be installed.

(6) Many of the window sills are in very bad shape and some will have to be replaced in those rooms to which the boys have access.

(7) The tables in the pupils dining room were covered with linoleum which is now full of holes which have been carved therein. These tables should be recovered with masonite or similar material. For the purpose 16 pcs. each 2'6" X 8'0" are required.

(8) A number of the composition stair treads are badly cracked and should be replaced. One or two can be considered dangerous at present.

(9) The plaster and woodwork in the vestibules is in bad shape and should be repaired.

(10) The plaster above the toilet in the boys' dormitory is in bad shape and the toilet needs a new seat.

(11) The cement floors throughout the building need patching in many places.

(12) The insulation on the steam pipes should be renewed in a number of places, especially in the boys playroom.

(13) Main Roof - The felt covering is exposed in many places, the flashing is loose in places and the cement around the stone coping now appears to be mostly sand and needs renewing. The two ventilators have the louvres broken out and as these ventilators no longer serve any useful purpose they should either be removed or have the louvres boarded up and the ventilators made rain proof.

(14) The tops of the two chimneys over the boiler room are in very bad shape. The cement mortar has fallen out between the bricks for some distance below the chimney tops and the stone coping and upper bricks may fall before very long.
(15) The brick facing over the tile at the N.E. corner of the laundry is badly cracked and the bricks are beginning to fall off. The condition of the tile can not be ascertained until the brick facing is removed.

The wall at this corner of the laundry building is butted against by a concrete retaining wall which holds up the earth approach to the barn. To repair the laundry wall it will be necessary to dig out a portion of the earth fill and break out a section of the concrete retaining wall.

(16) Laundry Roof - This roof is in about the same condition as the main roof on the school building. The joints between the stone coping must be renewed and the ventilators which are no longer used should be removed.

(17) In the laundry the plaster on walls and ceiling around ventilators is badly damaged from the water which has leaked through around the ventilators. The insulation on the steam pipes needs renewing. The water storage tank for the school water supply is located in the laundry room. This tank was never painted and is now badly rusted. The scale should be cleaned off and the tank painted.

(18) The hot water heater for the staff water supply is now out of commission. The sections are in bad shape and need replacing. This heater is a Gurney No.907, Cottage Boiler.

From the above you will note that the work that should be done at this school requires the services of painters, roofers, bricklayers, carpenters, plumbers and perhaps a steamfitter, also that certain jobs must be done before others can be proceeded with. The painting can be done on a contract basis but most, if not all, of the other work will have to be done on a day labour or cost-plus basis.

In view of the above it is hereby recommended:

(1) That a sum of not less than $7,500.00 be provided for the purpose of completing as much of the above work as possible during the present season.

(2) That a contract for the painting of at least those parts of the building covered by the Crane's estimate be awarded as soon as possible.

(3) That arrangements be made immediately for the purchase of materials locally and the employment of the skilled labour necessary to complete the work which must be done in the interior of the building before the painting can be completed.

(4) That a local builder be employed to repair the chimneys and roof copings and to remove the ventilators. This work can hardly be done on anything other than a cost-plus basis.
(5) That, after the work covered by (4) has been done, a local roofing contractor be employed to make the necessary repairs to the roof. This will also have to be done on a cost-plus basis.

(6) That authority to arrange for the work and supervise same be issued either to the Regional Supervisor, Indian Affairs, Manitoba, or to this office.

The above work will require a certain amount of supervision and same could, if desired, be handled from this office, in view of the fact that it is necessary to pass this school several times each month while enroute to the Riding Mountain National Park.

While at the Brandon School the Rev. O. B. Strapp advised me that the wooden water tank at the source of the school water supply was badly in need of replacement, also that the pipe line from the spring to the tank was badly clogged. He stated that the situation at the spring had been previously investigated by engineers of the Engineering and Construction Division and it was his understanding that plans had been made for the installation of a new concrete tank at the spring.

In view of Mr. Strapp's understanding I made no investigation at the spring and am submitting no estimate on the repairs that are apparently necessary at the source of the school water supply.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Repairs to Roof,
Brandon Residential School,
Manitoba.

With reference to your notation dated July 13th on memorandum of July 11th from the Indian Affairs Branch in respect to repairs to the roof of above school, we have received a report from Mr. W.W. Perrie in which he includes the following comments on the roofs:

(a) Main Roof - The felt covering is exposed in many places, the flashing is loose in places and the cement around the stone coping now appears to be mostly sand and needs renewing. The two ventilators have the louvres broken out and as these ventilators no longer serve any useful purpose they should either be removed or have the louvres boarded up and the ventilators made rain proof.

(b) Laundry Roof - This roof is in about the same condition as the main roof on the school building. The joints between the stone coping must be renewed and the ventilators which are no longer used should be removed.

(c) That a local builder be employed to repair the chimneys and roof copings and to remove the ventilators. This work can hardly be done on anything than a cost plus basis.

(d) That, after the work under item (c) has been done, a local roofing contractor be employed to make the necessary repairs to the roof. This will also have to be done on a cost plus basis.

We agree that the work should be on a cost plus basis, as until repairs are actually under way, the extent of the work to be done cannot be safely estimated.

May it be pointed out that repairs made now may have to be repeated on other portions of the roof in four or five years and inspection and further repairs made at that time. Should funds be available it would be good policy to decide on a 20-year guaranteed roof now and avoid further vexation in this respect for years to come.

Should roof repairs however be decided upon, may we be advised if it is desired to have this Division arrange for the work and supervision or by Indian Affairs through their Regional Supervisor in Manitoba.

MEMORANDUM

General Repairs,
Brandon Residential School,

On June 10th Mr. W.W. Perrie, Supervising Engineer at our Regina office, was instructed to inspect and report on the condition of the above building. We are now in receipt of Mr. Perrie's report, and after some consideration, have made a separate report to you on items that refer specifically to roof repairs and which was sent to you on July 19th last.

The interior repairs to the building, requiring attention as stated in the report, are of considerable extent, no separate item however, being considered of too an extensive nature not to deserve attention, but added together form a rather deplorable picture of conditions due to lack of maintenance.

The report sums up as follows:

(a) That ceilings, walls and floors in classrooms, playrooms and toilets require to be entirely renewed and others to be repaired.

(b) Window sills require caulking and painting with some to be replaced.

(c) Toilets, taps, stair treads, insulation on steam pipes and concrete floors throughout all need attention.

(d) Some brick facing is cracked and needs repairs.

(e) The hot water heater for the staff water supply, is out of commission and some steam pipes require replacing.

This is a brief summary of conditions at this school, and Mr. Perrie recommends that a sum of not less than $7,500.00 be provided for the purpose of completing as much of the above work as possible during the present season.

The report further states:

(1) That a contract for the painting of at least those parts of the building covered by the Crane estimate be awarded as soon as possible.

(2) That arrangements be made immediately for the purchase of materials locally and the employment of the skilled labour necessary to complete the work which must be done in the interior of the building before the painting can be completed.

Director,

Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Should the above work be authorized, it will require a certain amount of supervision. May we be advised whether or not this Division will be required to provide name.

We attach herewith the complete report with a copy of Crane Brothers estimate of $3,791.50 for the cost of interior painting, which seems fair and reasonable in view of the scattered nature of the work to be done. July 8, 1949

Attention: Mr. Chas. H. Buck.
Re: Indian Residential School, Brandon,
Manitoba.

In accordance with your letter of June 10, 1949 I have made an inspection of this school and beg to report that the work now required may be referred to almost nothing as maintenance, which has apparently been deferred for at least several years. The school building generally is in the worst condition of any that I have visited to date and it is impossible to furnish you with definite cost estimates covering the many items that now require attention.

The major, but by no means the most important, matter that should now be attended to is the interior decorating of the school. Practically the whole interior of the school is badly in need of decorating and this is matters that, according to the Rev. O. B. Strapp, Principal, has been under consideration for some time. Apparently several estimates covering interior decorating have been obtained and submitted to Indian Affairs and I am forwarding herewith a copy of the latest which was obtained from Crane Bros., Brandon. This estimate, in the amount of $2,862.35 covers only those rooms that are most urgently in need of painting and this work, at least, should be done this year. The work could be done by Crane Bros. on the basis of the estimate submitted, or estimates could be obtained from other Brandon Contractors who might be asked to tender on the items covered by the Crane quotation.

The following additional items also require immediate attention at this school:

(1) The classrooms, although not included in the Crane estimate, are in need of attention. The plaster is badly cracked in places and should be repaired. Three 4' X 8' pieces of Ten-Test should be supplied for attachment to walls for use as notice boards in order to eliminate future damage to the walls.

(2) The walls of the boys' and girls' playrooms were lined with "V Joint" between the floor and the lower level of the windows. This "V Joint" has been broken out and the plaster beneath gouged out at every break. New "V Joint" could be installed but
the same thing would no doubt happen to it in a short time. It is therefore recommended that the walls in these rooms be faced with cement from floor to window level. This work will have to be done before the painting of these rooms could be finished.

(3) The drinking fountain in the girls' playroom is in such bad shape that it can no longer be used and has been disconnected. A new fountain should be installed.

(4) The taps for the wash basins in both the boys' and girls' washrooms are all in bad shape and all need replacing. The taps on the bath tubs are in a similar condition. New taps should be supplied, 50 for the wash basins and 5 for bath tubs.

(5) The toilets in the boys' and girls' lavatories are likewise in bad condition. The old type of toilet installed here is anything but sanitary and I would suggest that new toilets be installed.

(6) Many of the window sills are in very bad shape and some will have to be replaced in those rooms to which the boys have access.

(7) The tables in the pupils dining room were covered with linoleum which is now full of holes which have been carved therein. These tables should be recovered with masonite or similar material. For the purpose 16 pcs. each 2'6" x 5'0" are required.

(8) A number of the composition stair treads are badly cracked and should be replaced. One or two can be considered dangerous at present.

(9) The plaster and woodwork in the vestibules is in bad shape and should be repaired.

(10) The plaster above the toilet in the boys' dormitory is in bad shape and the toilet needs a new seat.

(11) The cement floors throughout the building need patching in many places.

(12) The insulation on the steam pipes should be renewed in a number of places, especially in the boys' playroom.

(13) Main Roof - The felt covering is exposed in many places, the flashing is loose in places and the cement around the stone coping appears to be mostly sand and needs renewing. The two ventilators have the louves broken out and as these ventilators no longer serve any useful purpose they should either be removed or have the louves boarded up and the ventilators made rain proof.

(14) The tops of the two chimneys over the boiler room are in very bad shape. The cement mortar has fallen out between the bricks for some distance below the chimney tops and the stone coping and upper bricks may fall before very long.
(15) The brick facing over the tile at the N.E. corner of the laundry is badly cracked and the bricks are beginning to fall off. The condition of the tile cannot be ascertained until the brick facing is removed.

The wall at this corner of the laundry building is butted against by a concrete retaining wall which holds up the earth approach to the barn. To repair the laundry wall it will be necessary to dig out a portion of the earth fill and break out a section of the concrete retaining wall.

(16) Laundry Roof - This roof is in about the same condition as the main roof on the school building. The joints between the stone coping must be renewed and the ventilators which are no longer used should be removed.

(17) In the laundry the plaster on walls and ceiling around ventilators is badly damaged from the water which has leaked through around the ventilators. The insulation on the steam pipes needs renewing. The water storage tank for the school water supply is located in the laundry room. This tank was never painted and is now badly rusted. The scale should be cleaned off and the tank painted.

(18) The hot water heater for the staff water supply is now out of commission. The sections are in bad shape and need replacing. This heater is a Gurney No.907, Cottage Boiler.

From the above you will note that the work that should be done at this school requires the services of painters, roofers, bricklayers, carpenters, plumbers and perhaps a steamfitter, also that certain jobs must be done before others can be proceeded with. The painting can be done on a contract basis but most, if not all, of the other work will have to be done on a day labour or cost-plus basis.

In view of the above it is hereby recommended:

(1) That a sum of not less than $7,500.00 be provided for the purpose of completing as much of the above work as possible during the present season.

(2) That a contract for the painting of at least those parts of the building covered by the Crane estimate be awarded as soon as possible.

(3) That arrangements be made immediately for the purchase of materials locally and the employment of the skilled labour necessary to complete the work which must be done in the interior of the building before the painting can be completed.

(4) That a local builder be employed to repair the chimneys and roof copings and to remove the ventilators. This work can hardly be done on anything other than a cost-plus basis.
(5) That, after the work covered by (4) has been done, a local roofing contractor be employed to make the necessary repairs to the roof. This will also have to be done on a cost-plus basis.

(6) That authority to arrange for the work and supervise same be issued either to the Regional Supervisor, Indian Affairs, Manitoba, or to this office.

The above work will require a certain amount of supervision and same could, if desired, be handled from this office, in view of the fact that it is necessary to pass this school several times each month while enroute to the Riding Mountain National Park.

While at the Brandon School the Rev. O. B. Strapp advised me that the wooden water tank at the source of the school water supply was badly in need of replacement, also that the pipe line from the spring to the tank was badly clogged. He stated that the situation at the spring had been previously investigated by engineers of the Engineering and Construction Division and it was his understanding that plans had been made for the installation of a new concrete tank at the spring.

In view of Mr. Strapp's understanding I made no investigation at the spring and am submitting no estimate on the repairs that are apparently necessary at the source of the school water supply.

Dear Mr. Ferrie:

Sometime ago I contacted Rev. O. Sharpe at the Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man. Since my last contact with him I have been transferred to Saskatoon, but Rev. Sharpe sent a letter to our office in Toronto asking that a representative see him in regard to the roofs at the School, so I have had my contractor in Brandon check over the roofs and give me a resume of the existing conditions.

The condition of the roofs are as follows:

Copings - 1270 lineal feet.
These copings are of precast stone and numerous joints are open or cracked, and the present porosity is below normal allowing moisture to penetrate down into the parapet wall. The joints where open or cracked should be raked out and a heavy Tremco Mastic Caulking Compound applied by gun. After this has been done a waterproofing material should be trowelled over the entire stone so as to make it impervious to moisture, and thus prevent any further deterioration. This mastic waterproofing material is trowelled on at about 1/8" and has sufficient oils and fibre to allow for expansion and contraction and yet make it 100% waterproof.

Parapets - As mentioned above, the moisture has caused cracking and opening of joints in the parapet which should be sealed or pointed with Tremco Caulking & Pointing Compound. To further counteract deterioration, a coat of 14% Clear Damproofing should be applied. This prevents further moisture getting into the brick and seals the porosity of both the brick and mortar joints.

Flashings - The general condition of the flashings if fair except for the reglet, or leading edge, which is cracked and pulled away causing moisture to backpass the present flashings. If this is not attended to immediately, the coming winter will completely push out the flashing and cause considerable amount of damage to the existing well and present roof deck. A trowel application of a material called E.L.S. Mastic Roof Cement should be placed over the crack or seam through out the distance of 1270 feet, so as to prevent any further damage. The E.L.S. should be applied at approximately 5 lineal feet to the pound.

Projections - Any projections can be dealt with in the same manner as the flashings and when coating the roof any metal work can be covered by the roof preservative, which is a rust inhibitive material and thus prevents any further rusting of the metal.

Roof - There is approximately 13,000 sq. ft. of roof, all of which is of tar and gravel construction. Throughout all the roofs numerous bare spots are noticeable and a general dried out condition exists. The bare spots can be merely covered but this is taking a chance as numerous small areas can be missed and thus...
A complete and thorough job of proper maintenance is not accomplished. Therefore, the recommendation is to remove the existing gravel, as much as possible, and give a heavy application of Tremco Roof Preservative at the rate of 3½ to 4 gallons per square (100 sq. ft.). This resaturates and revitalizes the felts and prevents further drying out.

On some spots on the roof the felts are ripped, and where this has occurred the weakened area should have a trowel application of E.L.S. Mastic Roof Cement after which a jute fabric is embedded into the material and this in turn is followed by a further coat of E.L.S. The same procedure is followed where the existing blisters are sufficiently bad to warrant attention. The blister should be slit and the felts folded back and E.L.S. trowelled into and around the blister, then the felts are folded back into position and the same procedure as previously stated pertaining to rips is continued.

After the above repairs have been completed, the roof is then coated with Tremco Roof Preservative.

The materials required are as follows:

**Copings**
- 60 gals. 101 Mastic Waterproofing, Trowel consistency, Natural Cement Colour - $278.50
- 10 gals. 101 Primer - $35.50

Total - $314.00

**Parapets**
- 40 Gals. 145 Clear Damproofing - $204.00
- 3 Gals. Tremco Caulking & Pointing Compound - $15.60

Total - $219.60

**Flashings**
- 300 lbs. E.L.S. Mastic Roof Cement - $15.50
- 2 Rolls 12" Impregnated Jute Fabric - $10.70
- 500 Gals. Tremco Roof Preservative - $851.20

Total - $851.20

$1,431.30

The prices quoted above are F.O.B. Winnipeg and subject to existing sales tax.

Mr. R. O. Ellis is the contractor who looked over the roofs, and I would recommend him to do the work as he is fully familiar with Tremco methods and is most dependable and satisfactory, with efficient workmanship. Mr. Ellis's address is 420 - 7th St., Brandon, Man., and if you contact him he will be able to give you an estimate of the labour involved.

If there are any further details you desire, do not hesitate to get in touch with me.

Cordially yours,

Re: Brandon Indian Residential School

Mr. Strapp has sent me a copy of a circular letter which has been addressed to the Principals of all Indian Residential Schools, directing their attention to the fact that the Department has been experiencing considerable difficulty in some residential schools with residue collecting in catch basins and septic tanks. Mr. Davis instructs that all catch basins and septic tanks should be cleaned out at least once a year.

Mr. Strapp has replied to the circular and I am enclosing a copy of his letter. I do not know whether the matter has been referred to you but I thought that at least you should have it on record.

Dear Sirs;-

Re- Proposed Dairy Barn at Indian Residential School, Brandon, Manitoba.

I have been pressed by Mr. Hamilton to give a quotation on erecting the shed which was delivered from Shilo, for a proposed Dairy Barn.

On examination of the shed, I find the following;-

Walls. The walls are in sections 8 ft. wide x 12 ft. high. It would be necessary to cut the wall down to about 6 ft., to set on the proposed concrete walls. The windows and doors in these sections would have to be all changed in height and location, which would involve more work than framing a complete new wall. The walls are covered with 5/8 x 8 bevelled spruce boards 8 ft. long, which would not give a very good appearance for a new Building, being in 8 ft. lengths and straight joints. Shiplap would have to be purchased to line up the inside of the Building. The 3 Ply which was formerly used on the roof could be used to cover the ceiling inside; it also might be advisable to use the present siding to cover the inside of walls and purchase new siding for the outside.

Roof. I find that there are only 15 sets of 2 x 6 rafters for the roof, with 2 x 4 collar ties or joists, which would mean the rafters would be over 7 ft. apart - which should be only 2 ft. OC at the most for a permanent building. Then again, the 2 x 4 joists would not be strong enough to carry a litter carrier. The roof of this shed has previously been covered by 3/8 - 3 Ply sheeting, which would not be satisfactory to nail shingles on; therefore, new shiplap would have to be purchased, also shingles and cornice.

Having already submitted a firm quotation for the construction of walls and floor, and an alternative price of Cost Plus 10% for supervision, I would be pleased to give a quotation for completing the building of a new Barn of proper construction using what materials are available out of sections of shed which are on the ground, or as an alternative I would supervise the construction of a complete new Barn on a Cost Plus basis of 10%, or for a set fee.

Yours truly,

H.D. Spratling

DATE November 2nd, 1949
Personal & Confidential

Dear Mr. Murray,

I wonder if by writing this note I could help you to know more fully a local situation which has given me many hours of worry and indeed much concern.

As long as I have known Burnton School it has been the dumping ground for truancy pupils from other schools, mostly Manitoba schools but schools in Saskatchewan. This type of pupil has left its mark. This year encouraged by expulsion some 24 pupils have run away. I recall a similar situation some 25 years ago.

Just prior to the day he leaving discipline was slipping and the boys attacked Dr. Doyle one evening striking him badly. Fortunately members of the staff was near and so prevented further trouble.

Mr. Chapman took charge of this but only retained the position 2 years. The children ran wild and staff members were even afraid to go into certain dormitories alone. When Mr. Chapman left panels of doors were missing, lights were off others and even the private panes of glass had to be removed replaced. This was the heritage handed to Mr. Shipp. The condition today is changed but not without severe measures. As the Principal naturally is not too popular.
It is not hard to understand the reason. I reported on the recent vacancy but I do not know if you received a copy. It is my personal belief that most our pupils had a just reason for leaving—except perhaps the little chap away from home for the first time and he was lonely for his baby brother. There was the food complaint—but there must come a limit to this unless we expect to operate a Fort Garry or Prince Edward dining-room. When we show what these same children set down to at home & then see them in the school dining-room will be as different as day is from night. I believe there is plenty of food for all and I find it well served.

Our other real worry is the new barn—there is no authorized plan, specifications and at best it looks like a patched-up job. The Principal has ideas—some good & some bad till he has nothing to do with the building program—I am to get the work done under very difficult instructions & so I place that all materials—all possible plans and all unforeseen problems will be laid at my feet & there is nothing I can do—to me to explain to and get the careful considered help one in the field so urgently needs. I think tonight I may secure one quotation on the cement work—but for erecting the walls & completing the building I trust if anyone will touch it except on a cost-plus basis. One man said he firmly believed he could build the 4 walls
in a proper manner with new lumber,
for the money it will take to cut down
and piece together the old building. The
windows are wrongly located, also the
doors, & the 12 ft. height will need to be
cut down to from 6½ li 7½ ft. Siding spaces
will be high & the present walls will need
modulation as well as inside shelving. A
joint will occur every 8 ft all around the
building.

I am sorry to bother you - very if I
have done wrong in writing this personal
letter but I have been worried sick and
if this makes any clearer the whole situation
and by chance helps you in an decision
then it has been well worth while.

Please consider this strictly personal
and Confidential.

Kindest regards from Mrs Hamilton-
Jay and myself.

Sincerely Yours
A.J. Hamilton

On Tuesday, Nov. 22nd, I visited the above school with Mr. H. Spratling. I found that he had practically completed all plaster repairs required on the ground and first floors. The contractor had arranged to have the roofing repairs begin on Monday last, but due to the snowfall this work was postponed. Up until last Monday, he had been unable to obtain a man to do this work.

Brandon, Man.
Nov. 23rd, 1949.

Re: Work at Brandon Indian School.

On Tuesday, Nov. 22nd, I visited the above school with Mr. H. Spratling. I found that he had practically completed all plaster repairs required in the ground and first floors. It would be possible for the painting contractors to commence work on these two floors but as yet no paint has arrived. Rev. S. Strapp, Principal, to whom paint is consigned, will notify Crane Bros. as soon as paint is received.

Mr. Spratling has also completed the following: 2 toilet bowls have been replaced in boy's section (the soil stack joining these two toilets to main sewer below is in very poor shape and must be replaced), ventilators atop building have been bricked in, chimney tops have been repaired (the upper 6 feet on the north chimney were rebuilt and about the upper 2 feet on south one), and the brick facing at the north-east corner of the building has been repaired but it did not appear that the concrete wall had been shortened.

The cement and plaster work in the basement remains to be done and Mr. Spratling has not yet received the material that he intended to use on the lower four feet of basement walls.

The contractor had arranged to have the roofing repairs begin on Monday last, but due to the snowfall this work was postponed. Up until last Monday, he had been unable to obtain a man to do this work.

The repairs to the stone copings remains to be done.
The work at this school appears to be progressing favorably but it would appear that the roof repairs might not be completed this season. Mr. Spratling stated he would try to locate the bad leak in the laundry room and affect a repair to it.

Yours truly,

"W. J. Kerr"

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Ré: Brandon Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie Indian Agency,
Electoral District of Brandon,
Province of Manitoba.

The main barn at the above residential school was destroyed by fire during the winter of 1948.

In a memorandum dated October 3rd, 1949, the Acting Minister approved purchase of a building, 96' x 31', which was owned by North American Buildings Limited and located at Shilo Military Camp. This barn has now been delivered to the school.

Regional Supervisor Davis has secured the undermentioned tenders for excavating for footings, supplying and placing the necessary fill, supplying crib work, and supplying and placing concrete, supplying all necessary reinforcing, and supplying and placing four steel rods in the walls. The persons tendering are also prepared to supply and place mesh reinforcing for the concrete floor, do all the necessary forming for aisles, stalls and mangers, and pour the concrete floor.

(1) H.D. Spratling, General Contractors,
1217 - 13th Street, Brandon, Manitoba....$4,300.00

(2) Joe Holloway, Contractor,
2029 McDonald Avenue, Brandon, Manitoba...$4,475.00

Regional Supervisor Davis recommends the acceptance of the lower tender, and I concur in this recommendation.

Re: Brandon Indian Residential School

I desire to confirm the following army signal sent to you this morning:

"Reference army signal December 10 advising that tender of H.D. Spratling had been accepted for barn at Brandon Residential School, we have reviewed correspondence and find it necessary to have more definite information before Mr. Spratling proceeds with the work. Advise him at once to delay work until we give further orders."

Our reason for sending the above communication is due to the fact that we have reviewed previous correspondence, and before proceeding we wish to have some definite assurance regarding the total cost of the barn.

No doubt you have on file a copy of Mr. Connolly's letter of August 29th, offering us the building at Camp Shilo at a cost of $2,675.00 delivered to the Brandon School. We approved purchase of this building, and arrangements were made accordingly. The third paragraph of this particular letter reads as follows:

"It is estimated that the erection cost will be $300.00 and shingling would cost in the vicinity of $500.00."
When we first read Mr. Spratling's tender of October 26th, copy of which is enclosed, we were under the impression that his tender of $4,300.00 would be sufficient to provide the foundation and erect the building. However, on rereading his letter of October 27th, copy of which is also enclosed, we are not certain that our first impression was correct.

It would appear from very careful reading of Mr. Spratling's latter letter that Mr. Spratling considers it is going to be a rather costly job to complete the barn, even after spending $4,300.00 for the work mentioned in his letter of October 26th. If so, this information is considerably different from the information contained in Mr. Connolly's letter of August 29th.

Before proceeding further, we would like to have a complete report from you answering the questions raised in this letter.

We have had some unfortunate experiences in awarding contracts on a cost plus basis, and it is our intention to avoid these in future.

We are not prepared to proceed further at the present time until we receive for consideration a quotation on fully completing the barn.

I suggest you interview Mr. Connolly of North American Buildings Limited with a view to obtaining a price from him.

Bernard F. Neary,

at Brandon, which is also the choice of the Rev. Dr. Sutherland, after a personal inspection.

In recommending the Brandon site the Commissioner desires me to point out that the half section adjoins the Experimental Farm, which he considers is likely to afford advantages to the pupils in the way of instruction and of employment for some of them, as they become advanced.

He thinks moreover that heretofore in the location of such schools, we have been inclined to go somewhat too far away from the line of traffic, and that much more interest might be taken by the public generally, and the Church concerned, in particular, in a school kept as prominently before the public eye, as would be the case, were the site now recommended adopted.

The terms of purchase offered, he considers very easy, and is under the impression that the lands would be taken in exchange where already set apart by Order-in-Council (vide Department's letter 16th February last) if so desired.

There was at one time an inclination in the Commissioner's mind to prefer a site further South, because he felt a doubt as to whether parents would consent to sending their children, for whose benefit the school is proposed to be erected and maintained, to so great a distance, but he has since come to the opinion that this will not offer any serious difficulty.

near Selkirk.

The money provided, and as stated by Department to Dr. Sutherland, to be devoted in estimates for the approaching fiscal year, would be insufficient, and the Commissioner suggests that the money for the second building at Red Deer, might be diverted, for the present, from that purpose, and applied on the school now under consideration.

Sir:-

During the past few days I have made, in company with the Revd. J. Woodsworth, a careful examination of certain proposed sites for an Indian Institute at Carberry and Brandon. Taking into account all the circumstances we have come to the conclusion that the site offered by the Corporation of Brandon, adjoining the experimental farm on the West, is the most suitable, and I would therefore request, on behalf of the Methodist Church, that the proposed institute be located there. The site consists of a half section, part of which has been, for some years under cultivation. There is good variety of soil, and several springs of water issuing from the hillside can easily be utilized for the purposes of the Institution.

I have been given to understand that the present proprietor reserves the growing crops, but in view of the delay that has already occurred, and the importance of proceeding promptly with the work, I would suggest the propriety of negotiating with Mr Stewart for the purchase of the crops as improvements. If this is done we could almost immediately put a competent Farmer in charge, and by next Autumn quite a supply of breadstuffs would be available for the purposes of the Institution, with but little expenditure beyond the cost of seed and planting.

The
The present house could be quickly fitted for the occupancy of the Farm Instructor, and the present barn would shelter a few head of stock till a better one could be built. In this connection I would suggest a spot nearly in line with Mr Stewart's house, but a few hundred yards farther west, as a suitable site for the Institute.

We will be ready, at almost any time to nominate a principal, and I very much desire that we may be allowed a choice in regard to some, at least, of the Employees.

Our aim will be to nominate only persons who are thoroughly competent in their respective departments, and whose moral influence will be of the best. The importance of this latter element you will readily appreciate.

In view of the prominent site to be occupied by the Institute, in full view of Brandon and the C. P. Railway, immediately adjoining the experimental farm, and near the branch asylum, and other public buildings, I feel sure you will see the necessity for making it a model alike in its architecture and equipment. This done, I can assure you we will do our best to make it a model in regard to management and results. At the beginning it should be large enough to accommodate at least one hundred children, with provision for enlargement as circumstances require.

Touching the future relation of the Institute to the Government on the one hand, and the Church on the other, I think that for the first two or three years, which will be the construction period, the entire cost of maintenance should be provided by the Government. When the buildings are
are fully completed, necessary stock and implements provided, and the farm put in a position to raise a part, at least, of the needed supplies, we will be ready to assume responsibility for maintenance on the basis of a per capita grant. At the present stage we could hardly do this.

Hoping that this important enterprise will now be pushed forward to completion,

I have etc,

Referring to your letter of the 6th June last, No. 64411, respecting the Industrial Indian School at Brandon, I am directed to state as follows:

The deed to the Crown and documents which accompanied the above mentioned letter, respecting the East Half of Section 28, Township 10, Range 19, West of the 1st Meridian, have been examined and the title to that half-section appears to be satisfactory.

However, as the practice which has lately been adopted here in all cases of surrender or grant of lands in Manitoba or the Territories, to Her Majesty, is to apply for and obtain a certificate of title under the system of registration commonly known as the "Torrens System," it is deemed advisable that a certificate should be asked for in this instance.

As the deed of the land in question is to Her Majesty, as represented by the Surveyor-General of Canada, and as the purpose for which the land is to be used is one which is altogether under the control of your Department, and which does not in any way affect the affairs of this Department -- except only

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letters of the 19th and 29th December ultimo, the latter covering copy of extracts from a letter from Rev. Dr. Sutherland to the Minister respecting the possible purchase by the Department of an additional half-section of land adjoining the Indian industrial school at Brandon. You asked me to look into the matter and report at my earliest convenience.

My reply has been delayed in the hope that I might be able to visit Brandon School next week after I was through with the December returns, and discuss the whole question with the Principal of the institution. The Deputy's telegram of yesterday afternoon, however, calls for an immediate report and I respond because it is improbable that a visit to the school would alter my views on the subject.

Rev. Dr. Sutherland gives a two-fold reason why the acquisition of this land by the School is very desirable. His first reason is that it would enable the Principal to provide, if possible, for all the needs of the Institute without applying to the Government for anything but the per capita grant. I do not think the proposed purchase would accomplish so much. Repairs and improvements to all Industrial School

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
School establishments cost a large amount, and the Principal could not provide for them out of the sale of the surplus products of the farm. It might enable him to purchase the necessary implements, machinery and stock; but it appears clear to me that the main object of the application for this land is that its acquisition would be a means of supplementing the per capita grant. If this grant is insufficient let the Department increase it, but I do not think it should depart from its present policy of providing the Industrial Schools with enough land to afford scope for the training of the Indian boy pupils in mixed farming, and incidentally supplying the schools with such vegetables, milk, butter, feed and a portion of the meats they require. If we go beyond that we enter upon doubtful ground. Rev. Mr. Ferrier, the present Principal of the Brandon School, is an excellent manager, and I have every confidence that he could make a large farm contribute to the finances of the institution; but no man is a permanency in any situation; he may be called to other duties, and his successor may fail to make valuable land yield an adequate return.

In regard to Rev. Dr. Sutherland's second reason for applying to the Department to purchase the half-section of land named at $30.00 per acre—in all $9600.00—I would not object to the expenditure if it was absolutely necessary to obtain land for the school to afford a fair scope for training Indian pupils; but, as you point out the Brandon School has already 320 acres of land, 220 of which are fit for cultivation, it appears to me that this quantity is sufficient to allow ample opportunity for training in mixed farming, when it is considered that a portion of the boys' time must also be devoted to class work.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 26th Ult., in which you request me to make a report on an application you have received from the Secretary Treasurer of the Municipality of Cornwallis for a grant for the grading and graveling of a road through the Indian Industrial School farm, Brandon; and stating that the estimated cost is $500.00. Acting on the instructions contained in your letter, I visited Brandon on the 29th Ult. and went thoroughly into the matter.

The road in question runs east and west through the experimental farm, and through the school lands and continues in a westerly direction.

I understand this road was given by the Government, through the experimental farm, to the Corporation of the City of Brandon, and through the School lands to the Municipality of Cornwallis, in lieu of the sectional roads to the north and south, running in the same direction, which, owing to the formation of the country, could only be opened at a very considerable cost. The sectional road allowance to the south of the Farm,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
crosses the Assiniboine River several times, which makes it impractical as a road. The Municipality have had to buy the continuation of the road west of the school property.

The road is now a public highway, much travelled, but not used to any extent by the school as they have an outlet through the Experimental Farm. The road in its passage through the Experimental Farm is kept in condition by the farm people, not as a matter of right, but because they desire a better road than the City could give them. For this reason they keep it in repair and it is a beautiful piece of highway.

I drove over the road through the School Lands. It is not in bad condition. Two thirds of it has been gravelled and graded, the balance is on the natural prairie. It is not nearly as good as the portion passing through the Experimental Farm, but I would consider it a fair road as it is.

To sum up; the road as I understand it is under the control of the Municipality and they are responsible for its condition. The Department did them a very kind action in giving them the road, as it cuts the farm in two, and runs through the best part of the arable lands.

No doubt the road could be much improved by grading and graveling, but the Municipality have no claim on the Department for the cost.

My recommendation is that as the School pays no taxes, and does no statute labor, that the Municipality be given a grant of $100.00, which would be about equal to one year's assessment. This could be continued from year to year if the Department think it advisable.
