Memorandum

Mr Pedley. Re Purchase of Land for Brandon Industrial School.

Rev. T. Ferrier, Principal of the Brandon Industrial School, has made application to the Superintendent General requesting the Department to purchase a quantity of land which he states is very much needed by the school for farming purposes.

The land at present connected with the school comprises 320 acres, being the east ½ of Section 28, Township 10, Range 19 west of the first meridian. 220 acres of this is excellent land and is under crop, the balance is used for buildings and playgrounds and for pasture.

The only land at present available, is the section adjoining the present school land, on the north. It is owned by a Scotch company who will sell the whole section (640 acres) en bloc at $25.00 per acre, but will not sell half or a part. The amount necessary to purchase the whole section at the price asked, is $16,000.00.

During
During my visit to Brandon last summer I went thoroughly over the school land in company with Mr Ferrier and recognized that it would be necessary before long to acquire more land for this school, especially for pasturage purposes. A fifty acre lot which they have had rented from the Experimental farm for the past six years has now been taken over by the farm. They have a herd of cattle for which it is necessary that arrangements be made to provide pasturage.

If it is decided to purchase this section, only one half (320 acres) will be required for the use of the school and the balance could be disposed of, or if held for a time would no doubt increase in value. It would not be difficult to find sale for the half section not required.

There are no funds specially provided in the current year's school appropriation for this purchase, but if it is decided to acquire more land for this school, some arrangement could possibly be made to provide the money required.

We will undoubtedly have to maintain this school, and as it is one of the best training schools we have, I think we should make it thoroughly efficient.

Dear Sir:

Replying to yours of September 26th, re the fencing of the section of land recently purchased by the Department for the use of the Brandon Industrial School.

Now that the section has been purchased, it will be better to fence the whole of it since by so doing the value will be increased, and the chances of selling it should the Department wish to dispose of one-half of it, will be greater than in its present condition. It may be said that if it is fenced and worked as the management are planning to work it, it will become more valuable the longer we work it, and thus easier of sale.

I may also say that without the fence, it is absolutely useless for school purposes, for there is nothing we can do with it except herd our cattle upon it. This would require the attention of herd boys day and night in order to keep them from our neighbor's crop.

I have been making further enquiries re the cost of fencing, and I find that it will take about $300.00 a mile. One tender I received was as high as $350.00 per mile. This, I think, was beyond the real value.

I would like to know at the earliest possible date so that we might put up a part of this fence this Fall before the frost enters the ground; and it is the best time of the year to secure labor for that purpose.

Trusting to have a favorable reply,

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir,

Since this Institution was opened in 1895, those who have died have been buried at the lower end of the farm close to the Assiniboine River. The City purposes negotiating with the Department for a portion of that land to be used as a Park. The time has come when we should cease burying any more in that plot of land, for the following reasons:

It is close to the Banks of the Assiniboine River, from which the City supply of water is taken, and above the intake of that water supply. The soil is perfectly dry and hard, with no sign of spring formation, and I do not for one moment think that any seepage has occurred from this burying plot to contaminate the water of the river in any degree. About two weeks ago I requested the civil engineer and the health inspector of the City of Brandon to come over and interview me regarding the matter. We discussed the situation, and came to the conclusion that in-as-much as the general public might have an opportunity in the future of observing this burying ground from a public park, some sentiment might arise regarding the matter, therefore I believe that it is unwise to continue burying in that plot of land.
We have now a section of land to the North. I have gone over this this morning for the purpose of locating a suitable and proper site for a burial plot, believing that we will have to use it in the near future for three pupils whom I have mentioned in another communication. I would like the consent of the Department to the changing of the burying ground to this new site, and also the authority of the Department to fence it properly.

My own thought for a fence would be a beautiful picket fence painted white, with properly dressed and finished cedar posts. The site I propose would be 150 feet by 75 feet. The exact cost of the fence I have not figured out, but will if the Department consents to the changing and the fencing of the plot.

I would also suggest the advisability of placing in the centre of the plot a plain stone monument with four smooth sides upon which might be chiseled the name and date of death of every child buried therein.

The Department's views upon this matter will be appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Scott:

Replying to yours of July 26th, I submit the following report re the work on the hill and the road between this and the Experimental Farm.

The City Council had their City Engineer, Mr. Speakman, survey the hill and road, and Mr. Smith, the City Foreman of Public Works oversee the execution of the work. From the entrance to the Indian School Farm to the top of the grade is about 1500 feet. This has been cut down and filled up to a uniform grade of about 7½%. The top of the road-bed is 24 feet wide and covered with about 6 inches of gravel. This road-bed has a ditch on each side. The water which gathers from the top of the hill to about half way down is run off into the ravine. The water which gathers from the middle of the hill is well taken care of in 2 glazed-pipe culverts, 18 inches in diameter with a cement wall at each end.

From the entrance to the Farms to the south road running East and West through the Farms is 1850 ft. This has been graded with the clay cut out of the hill and is covered with about 6 inches of gravel. This road-bed is 20 ft wide in the top.

The road-way from the entrance to the Farms has been brushed and ploughed. The work has been well supervised and well executed and is a first class job. In my judgment the money has been well and economically expended.

The $2000 given by the Government was sufficient to do the work with the exception of putting a coat of gravel on the grade of 1850 ft from the entrance to the Farms to the south road. This required about 600 cu. yards of gravel. To make a complete finish, the Brandon City Council paid $100, the Cornwallis Municipality $100 and the Indian School another $100. So you will see that for the entire work, the cost is $2300. We have now a first-class road. It is the intention of the management of the school to keep it in repair.

I have very much pleasure in submitting this favorable report.

Yours sincerely,

T.F./M.C.B.

FRIDAY, APRIL 16, 1920

WANTED! A PARK

Versacious delays in connection with securing title to the new Suburban Park, should not be permitted to block the plans and efforts that have been made to give Brandon people a real playground for this Summer. If the Parks Board permits them to, it will show itself singularly out of touch with popular sentiment.

The time wasters at Ottawa, may not be able to straighten out the difficulties concerning legal technicalities over the delivery of title, but this should not be permitted to interfere with development plans. As it is generally understood, the principals in the deal have signified their willingness to make the transfer. They should be asked to sign so in writing, and have done so. Development be proceeded with immediately the ground is fit. Then the time wasters can move along in their leisurely fashion without interference on our part.

Nothing less than the adaptation of the natural facilities of the site to the use of a suburban park, early this Spring, should be the objective of the Parks Board. If this body finds obstruction in the way of finances or labor, an appeal to the red-blooded men of Brandon to turn out on an agreed day, say Arbor Day, May 16th, and "brush up" the park, will meet with a hearty response.

Though there is no expectation that in one short season Brandon can effect the transformation of this site from a wilderness and scrub into a complete natural park, yet a great deal can be done if there is the right blend of wise leadership, enthusiasm and effort.

There does not appear to be any reason why the underbrush cannot be removed, some roads cut, a cattle-shanty built, and a store set up, to provide hot water, an athletic ground laid out, a bathing beach staked and roped off to make it safe for swimmers old and young, tables and benches erected, and other facilities installed essential to a picnic grounds.

There is no secret about what should be provided in order to attract holiday makers. Hundreds of men and women can name them off without stopping to think. Most of the fundamentals are not costly. What is transportation will have to be arranged for is leadership.

Though the park project can never be the success it should be until some means of transportation is provided this year, delay in taking action to provide desirable park facilities, at this natural beauty spot, and the most required if these are to be arranged.

Brandon has a potential asset in its park. Left as it is, this asset is valueless. Equipped as it can be, easily and inexpensively, it will yield returns in healthful vigor, in enjoyment of life and living, in a splendid sham parking throughout the coffee season, and business houses, benefitting everybody.

Are we then content to accept the passive assurance that the title difficulties cannot be overcome in time for work to be made to have the park in shape next Summer. Certainly not. Brandon demands this park, this Summer.

WHY IS BRANDON LEFT OUT?

An order-in-council, issued by the government of Manitoba, authorizes the expenditure of $516,599 for the extension of the hydro-electric project under the Manitoba Power Commission.

It is proposed to tap the power line to Portage la Prairie and run a line or lines to Carman, Borden, Roland, Winkler, Manitou and Gladstone. The balance of the money to be spent for the purpose is expected providing for construction and surveying.

Brandon is one of the points in this province where there is a demand for cheap electric power. A committee of the Board of Trade has been busy on this question for some time past. The City Council likewise has a committee. Other places in the province seem to be unable to get linked up with this big project. Brandon appears to be getting nowhere.

There must be a reason. The public is entitled to it. If it is left to political considerations, with an election coming on, the people might be somewhat skeptical. Politicians have been known, during election times, to present one certain aspect of a situation, except of course, favorable to themselves and their party.

Brandon people are entitled to the truth about the electric power question without delay.

FARMERS AND LABOR

Hours of labor is the only thing against which efforts to unite farmers and labor beats in vain. Mr. Macdonald combines in his person both bosses and the laborers. He is able to rob both sides of the park road, maples and elms being the possible selections.

Except for some under scrub being cut away, it is not expected that much of this work will be attempted this year.

Memorandum:

Honourable Mr. Meighen,

In regard to letter from the City Clerk of Brandon, of the 13th January last, submitting an offer to lease a portion of the Brandon Industrial school lands, I would point out that under Order of His Excellency in Council of the 8th of August, 1900, the E.½ of sec. 28, in tp.10, rge.19, w.1st M., was set apart and appropriated for the purposes of an Indian Industrial School.

The portion applied for by the City Clerk for park purposes comprises an area of 57.64 acres, and an offer has been made of the sum of $6,000 for this property, for the full term of ninety-nine years with a privilege at the end of that term if said park is continued, that the lease shall be renewed for a further term.

Rev. Mr. Ferrier is desirous of having the amount paid as rental used in connection with the management of the Brandon Institute. This arrangement, if carried out, might be considered as a compliance with the Order in Council setting aside the land for Industrial School purposes.

In transmitting a cheque for the sum of $6,000 to the Department, it is represented by the City Clerk that in addition to the lease of the land in question, a roadway one hundred feet wide, giving access to the park grounds from the main road running through the experimental and
industrial farms, at a point to be decided upon between Rev. Mr. Ferrier and the City Council, early in the Spring of 1920, would require to be arranged. Mr. Ferrier assures me that this roadway will be arranged to the satisfaction of the city.

This is a matter in which the city of Brandon is deeply interested, as the possession of this property will give them a fine park and recreation ground; the land is not required for the Industrial School, but the money is, as will be seen by Mr. Ferrier's letter addressed me on the 14th January, 1920.

I see no reason why this arrangement should not be carried out, and ask for your approval.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Your letter of July 12th is received with enclosure as stated.

A Plan is being made of the proposed road and will be sent you in a short time. The original allowances for road that you refer to can only be closed by the Municipality and conveyed to the Department under the provisions of the Municipal Act of this Province, which authorizes the Municipality to deal with these. This requires Notices to be posted thirty days before the By-laws closing the roads can be passed. Then the By-law has to receive the assent of the Lieutenant-Governor-in-Council of Manitoba. After these formalities have been complied with, the Municipality can deal with the original allowances for road. We have no doubt that there will be no difficulty or obstacle except that of time, in carrying out what you suggest.
The Municipal Act provides that when original allowances for road, such as in the present case, are closed, they must be sold to the owners of the lands adjoining these original allowances for road.

In the case of the portion of the East road, the City of Brandon has acquired a portion of the land adjoining the allowance for road from the South East corner of the School farm to the South bank of what is called the "Slough" on the Blue Print, and the Experimental Farm, through the Department which manages that, owns the land on the East side of that piece of road. Herewith is a recommendation for the transfer to the Government of the Province of Manitoba, on behalf of the Rural Municipality of Cornwallis, of road allowance comprising 4.22 acres through the property of the Indian Industrial School at Brandon.

MEMO RE THE LAND USED BY
THE BRANDON INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

As early as 1898, Dr. A. Sutherland, of the General Board of Missions of the Methodist Church, pressed for the establishment of an industrial school for the benefit of children of Lake Winnipeg Indians. The Department's policy at that time was to establish institutions in white centres and to emphasize vocational training of pupils.

In 1899, the Department approved of the scheme and the question of a suitable site was given consideration. Various localities were suggested - Fisher River, Berens River and Selkirk. Dr. Sutherland, the Rev. John McBeugall and Dr. J. Woodsworth were in favour of a site in the southern part of the province. They were not satisfied, however, with the property near Carman, which was set aside by Order in Council for the school.

People of both Brandon and Carberry became interested and John Kerr, Clerk of the City of Brandon, wrote Rev. Mr. Woodsworth, of the Methodist Church, that the City Council would give a site next to the Experimental Farm and accept in exchange government lands elsewhere. Dr. Sutherland visited the West in 1891, examined the sites and recommended that the one at Brandon be secured. The City of Brandon purchased from J. W. Stewart the half section on which the school is situated. The price was $5,700. Mr. A. Kelly, Mayor of Brandon, wrote to the Department in 1891, accepting the section near Carman in trade for the site at Brandon. The site was occupied and the building operations commenced in 1892. In 1900, the deal was finally completed and regularized by Order in Council.

In 1911, the section on the hill was purchased for the use of the school for the sum of $16,000. In 1920, the City of Brandon completed a 99 year lease of the most southerly part of the school property for $6,000. 52 acres was required for municipal park purposes.

Private Secretary.
August 7, 1935.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a petition from the ratepayers of the Municipality of Cornwallis and the adjoining Municipalities in Manitoba, asking that the Department appropriate a sum of money for the surfacing of the road running East and West through the Brandon Indian School property.

It is represented that this portion of the highway has not been repaired for some years and that it is badly in need of surfacing.

Before giving any consideration to this petition I would like to be furnished with a report as to the actual condition of the road in question, also the nature of the repairs required, as well as the approximate cost of same.

You might also furnish a report as to the condition of the part of this road outside the Indian School property in comparison with the portion through the school property.

I am sending you a map of the school property on which I would ask you to kindly indicate the road in question.

Yours very truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

WINNIPEG, MAN., August 22nd, 1935.

Dear Sir:

In reply to Department Letter 133-0-9 dated August 7th, I wish to advise that I inspected the valley road which runs east and west through the Brandon Indian Residential School property.

This road, as shown by the map, turns west off 18th Street and the first mile passes through the Dominion Experimental Farm. I am informed by Mr. Hopper, Asst. Supt., that all the repair and upkeep of this road has been carried out by his Department. The half mile through the school property is certainly not in good condition and I understand from Dr. Doyle, Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School, that several cars and trucks were stuck on this portion of the road during the past spring and summer. West, and adjoining the school property, is the Country Club Golf Course and this half mile of road is in good shape. I understand some of the work in connection with this road is paid for by the Golf Club. The road running west from this point is gravelled and in fair condition.

In view of the fact that there is so much Government property along this road, it is perhaps only fair that some assistance should be given to the Municipality. The Dominion Experimental Farm have assumed their responsibility and it is perhaps only right that our Department should grant some assistance.

The Councillor states that the Road Engineer advises that it costs approximately $1200. per mile to properly gravel a market road. He thinks the Municipality should be granted $500, but adds that any assistance would be greatly appreciated. Dr. Doyle accompanied me on my inspection.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
inspection of the road and we are both of the opinion that the necessary work could be done for less money. I think if the Department were to allow $300., the repair work necessary could be carried out and the road made equally as good as any other portion I inspected.

In view of the information obtained, I would recommend that assistance be granted to the amount as stated above. I am returning herewith the two maps, showing the road in question marked in red ink.

I shall be glad to know the Department's decision in connection with this matter.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

August 31, 1935.

Mr. Buskard,

Memorandum:

Referring to your memorandum of the 1st instant and the petition from the ratepayers of the Municipality of Cornwallis and adjoining towns in Manitoba, asking this department for assistance towards the cost of surfacing a piece of road running East and West through the Brandon Indian Residential School property, I beg to advise that the Department is now in receipt of a report from Inspector A. G. Hamilton of Winnipeg, who made an inspection of the above mentioned road conditions.

According to the information given in this report it appears that the portion of the road in question, which has a length of about a half mile through the school property, is in a bad condition, and that the portions outside have been kept in fairly good shape by the interested parties.

The improvements required to put our portion of the road in a similar condition as the parts leading to it would consist in grading and surfacing with gravel at a cost estimated at approximately $500. It is considered, however, by the Inspector and Doctor Doyle, Principal of the School, that an amount of about $300 would be sufficient contribution by this department to put this portion of the road in as good condition as the portions outside the school property.

In view of the circumstances as set forth I would concur with Inspector Hamilton's recommendation that an amount of $300 be allowed the Municipality of Cornwallis to assist in the improvements applied for.

Deputy Superintendent General.
